form.definition: noun H or h is the eighth letter of the English alphabet.

noun A habit is something that you have got used to doing. You do it regularly. I'm in the habit of going for an evening stroll. He's got a strange habit of playing with his glasses while he talks. It's important to do it right and not fall into bad habits.
noun The habitat is the environment or conditions where plants and animals live. Australian native plants are well adapted to a hot, dry habitat.
verb If you hack at something, you chop or slash it roughly and with force. He hacked at the clump of grass with the blade. Don't just hack at it, cut it neatly.
verb If someone hacks into a computer system, they gain access to it although they are not authorised to do so.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hacker Security is poor and the system is vulnerable to hackers.

form.definition: noun A hacksaw is a saw that's used especially for cutting metal.
verb Had is the past tense and past participle of have.
verb Hadn't is the informal form of 'had not'.
noun Haemoglobin is the substance that gives blood its red colour and carries oxygen from the lungs to other tissue.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is hemoglobin.

form.definition: noun If you have haemophilia, your blood does not clot normally. It is a disease which can be passed down from parent to child.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is hemophilia. ... WORD FAMILYnoun haemophiliac (<or> hemophiliac)

form.definition: noun A haemorrhage is heavy bleeding inside a person's body. ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is hemorrhage. ... WORD FAMILYverb haemorrhage (<or> hemorrhage)
noun If you have haemorrhoids, the veins around your anus are swollen and painful.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is hemorrhoid.

form.definition: adjective If you are haggard, you look exhausted and sick. I was shocked by how haggard she looked. The haggard parents waited to hear if their son would survive.
verb If you haggle, you argue about the price of what you are buying. Jason tried hard to get the shopkeeper to lower the price of the carvingthey haggled over it for a long time.
noun Hail is small round pieces of ice, called hailstones, that sometimes fall from the clouds. It was a violent stormthe hail did a lot of damage to the garden.
verb If you hail a taxi in the street, you raise your arm so that the driver will stop for you. There's one with its light onstep out and hail it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hail It began to hail.

form.definition: noun Hair is the thin threads that grow from the skin on the top of your head and other parts of your body. I need to have my hair cut. He's got dark hair.
noun A hair is one of these thin threads. The cat's left black hairs all over the lounge!

get in your hair If someone gets in your hair, they annoy you by wanting your attention and interfering with what you're trying to do. I couldn't finish the job as the twins kept getting in my hair all day.

let your hair down If you let your hair down, you don't behave in a formal way. You relax and enjoy yourself. After the ceremony, the guests let their hair down and had a good time singing and dancing.

split hairs If you split hairs, you make a fuss about very small and unimportant differences. Let's not split hairsthey're both as bad as each other. ... WORD FAMILYadjective hairy (hairier, hairiest) Stephen's got a very hairy chest.
noun If you have a haircut, someone such as a barber or hairdresser cuts your hair. I'm about due for a haircut.
noun A haircut is also the way in which your hair is cut. Most of the girls have short haircuts.
noun Hairdo is a rather informal word for the way in which someone's hair is cut and styled. I like your new hairdo.
noun A hairdresser is a person who is trained to cut and style people's hair.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hairdressing Sara's studying hairdressing at TAFE.

form.definition: adjective If something is hair-raising, it is frightening or dangerous. The bus journey across the mountains was a hair-raising experience.
noun Your hairstyle is the way you wear your hair. Cynthia's new hairstyle suits her much better than the plaits.
noun A half is one of the two equal parts into which something can be divided. She cut the apple in half. The first half of the film was rather boring.
quantifier Half something is an amount equal to 50% of it. Add half a litre of water. Well over half our staff are graduates.
quantifier Half something is a considerable proportion of it. I don't understand her half the time. James has already eaten half the cakes.
noun Half is 50% of something. About half remained. Keep half of the mixture for a second layer. Half of the students study Japanese and half Korean.
noun Half is a considerable proportion of something. Half of what he says is rubbish anyway. Half of these clothes are worn out.

adverb When something is half done, it is partly done. It is not completely done, but it has been started. The work was half finished by lunchtime. We arrived at the party late and found the food was half eaten.
adverb When someone half does something, they do it partly or incompletely. He half smiled when he saw us. She half rose from her chair.
adverb If you are half happy and half sad, you are partly happy and partly sad. The strange creature was half man and half horse.
half a dozen Half a dozen means six or approximately that number. I bought half a dozen eggs. I could give you half a dozen reasons why not. Half a dozen of us stayed to clear up.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See halve.

form.definition: noun Your half-brother is a boy or man who has the same father as you but a different mother, or has the same mother but a different father.
adjective If you are half-hearted about something, you are not very keen or enthusiastic. They made a rather half-hearted attempt to clear up. He managed a half-hearted smile.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb half-heartedly

form.definition: noun Your half-sister is a girl or woman who has the same father as you but a different mother, or has the same mother but a different father.
adjective If something is described as halfway, it is equally distant from each of two points. The travellers had reached the halfway point of their journey.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb halfway She had walked halfway up the hill when her shoe broke.

form.definition: noun A hall is a passage in a building from which you can get to other rooms. You can also use hallway or corridor. The room you want is the second door on the left up the hall.
noun A hall is a large public building or room which can be used by the community. The school concert was held at the local hall.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See hallway.

form.definition: noun A hallmark is an official mark stamped on gold and silver objects to guarantee their purity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hallmark It must be real goldsee, it's hallmarked.

form.definition: verb If you hallucinate, you see and vividly experience things that are not really there. Jeff was so tired that he was beginning to hallucinate. Am I hallucinating, or is that Adnan? I thought he was interstate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hallucination These drugs may produce hallucinations. It must have been a hallucination.

form.definition: noun A hallway is a long, narrow area in a building along which you walk to get from one room to another.
form.note: ... OTHER WORDSfor this are corridor and hall.

form.definition: noun A halo is a circle of light that is drawn around the head of a holy person in religious pictures.
noun A halo is also a circle of light that can be seen around the sun and moon at certain times.
verb When you halt, you stop moving forward. I halted halfway up the hill to let the rest of the group catch up. You must halt at the intersection.

verb When you halt someone or something, you prevent them from moving forward or progressing. The police halted the demonstrators in front of the building. We must halt the increase in road accidents.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun halt Work on the project has come to a halt.

form.definition: verb If you halve something, you divide it into two equal parts. She halved the pie between us.
verb If you halve something, you reduce it by 50%. Low rainfall early in the season has halved this year's wheat crop. Our profits have halved over the last year.
noun Ham is salted or smoked meat that comes from the upper part of a pig's leg. I had two slices of ham and some salad. Butchers sell many whole hams at Christmas time.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective ham ...a ham sandwich. ...a ham salad.

form.definition: noun A hamburger is a bread roll filled with a flat fried cake of minced beef and usually onions and ketchup as well. Often you buy hamburgers as a takeaway meal.[qr

dictionary.entry:
hammer`hAm@
noun A hammer is a tool used to drive in nails. It has a heavy metal head and a handle.
2 noun The hammer on a gun is the part which fires the bullet when you pull the trigger.
... WORD FAMILYverb hammer Make sure you hammer the nail in straight.

form.definition: noun A hammock is a length of net or strong cloth which is tied to supports at both ends so that you can sleep in it.

noun A hamper is a large basket or box with a lid that is used for carrying or sending food. The charity workers were busy packing food hampers to distribute. She won a Christmas hamper in the raffle. I bought one of those wonderful traditional picnic hampers.

verb If something hampers someone or something, it makes it difficult for them to move or happen properly. My luggage hampered me in getting on the bus. Bad weather hampered the rescue of the lost hikers.
noun Your hamstring is a tendon at the back of your knee. She pulled a hamstring in the sprint final and came last.
noun Your hand is the part at the end of your arm below the wrist, including your fingers. Hold it with both hands. He had a bunch of flowers in his hand.
noun A hand on a dial or instrument is a pointer which shows a measurement. There is no second hand on this watch.
noun A hand is a worker or labourer. ...a factory hand. ...a farm hand. They're looking to take on more hands.
noun A hand is the set of cards you hold in a card game. Amal had the winning hand.
verb If you hand something to someone, you pass it from your hand into theirs. Could you hand me that spanner, please.
at hand If something is at hand, it is nearby and ready for use. Make sure that everything you need is at hand before you begin.
by hand If you do something by hand, you use your own hands to do it rather than a machine. She washed the clothes by hand. The computer was down so I had to write out the list by hand.
change hands When something changes hands, it passes from one owner to another. The property changed hands at $500 000.
give someone a hand If you give someone a hand, you help them. James gave Sarah a hand with her heavy luggage.
hand in If you hand something in, you submit or surrender it officially. All entries must be handed in by the end of next week. The police will not prosecute those who hand in firearms voluntarily.
hand out If you hand things out, you distribute them. We need volunteers to hand out how-to-vote cards. The waiters went round handing out savouries.
hand over If you hand something over to someone, you give it to them, often reluctantly. The robber forced him to hand over his wallet. I resent handing over nearly half my income to the government.
have your hands full If you have your hands full, you are fully occupied and can't take on any more tasks. Wai-Yi had her hands full cooking for sixteen over the New Year.
in hand (a) If something is in hand, it is under control or being attended to. Don't worry, I've got the problem in hand. Arrangements are already in hand for the centenary celebrations.
(b) The job in hand is the one you are dealing with now. We must resolve the matter in hand before we start anything else.
keep your hand in If you keep your hand in, you practise doing something so that you don't lose your skill at it. I try to play golf once a month so as to keep my hand in.
on hand If something is on hand, it is nearby and available. I'll be on hand if you've got any questions.
out of hand If something is out of hand, it is out of control. The party was quiet to begin with, but eventually it got out of hand and the police had to be called.
to hand If something is to hand, it is somewhere where you can find or reach it easily. I don't have your file to hand right now.
try your hand If you try your hand at something, you make an attempt to do it. I've always wanted to try my hand at painting with watercolours.
wash your hands of something If you wash your hands of something, you refuse to have any further responsibility for it. It didn't look like an honest deal, so he washed his hands of it.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See handout. adjective See manual.

form.definition: noun A handbag is a small bag which a woman carries around with her, containing things such as money, keys, pens and cosmetics. Katie bought a leather handbag to go with her smart new outfit.
noun Handcuffs are two metal rings connected by a short piece of chain. Police lock them around someone's wrists to prevent them from using their hands freely.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb handcuff He handcuffed himself to the railings. She was found gagged and handcuffed.

form.definition: noun A handful of something is the amount that you can grip with one hand. The boys threw handfuls of sand at each other. My hair was falling out by the handful.
noun A handful can also be a small amount or number of something. Hundreds of letters came in, but only a handful of them were complaints.

noun If you say someone is a handful, you mean they are difficult to control. They keep you busy. Leon discovered during the school holidays that the kids could be a real handful. You've certainly got a handful with that class!

noun A handicap is a physical or mental condition that makes it difficult for someone to carry out some of the activities of everyday life. Note that many people with such a condition prefer to call it a disability. Niko was born with multiple handicaps.
noun A handicap is something that makes it more difficult for you to achieve something. Not being able to speak Japanese is a big handicap if you want to do business in Japan.

noun A handicap is an advantage or disadvantage given to some competitors in a race or match, so that everyone has a more equal chance to win. The favourite in the Melbourne Cup will be carrying a 7 kg handicap. Jeff's a good golferhe plays off a handicap of nine.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb handicap (handicapped, handicapping) I was handicapped by my lack of experience.adjective handicapped The club was raising money for handicapped children.

form.definition: noun A handicraft is a skill, such as pottery, weaving, embroidery or sewing, which involves using your hands to make things. Why don't you learn a handicraft in your spare time?
noun A handicraft is also something that you make using such a skill. The children were eager to display their handicrafts at the school exhibition.

noun (<plural form> A handkerchief is a small, square piece of cloth or tissue that you carry with you. You can use it to blow your nose or wipe your face or eyes. He wore a silk handkerchief in his breast pocket.
form.note: ... AN INFORMAL SHORT FORMfor this is hankie.[qr

form.definition: noun A handle is the part of an object that you put your hand on in order to use, open or carry it. Turn this handle to the right. Pick it up by the handle, not by the lid. The handle had come off one of the drawers.

verb When you handle something, you touch it with your hands or you pick it up and move it. Don't handle the photos with your sticky fingers. These explosive substances can be very dangerous to handle. FRAGILE: HANDLE WITH CARE
verb If you handle a tool or machine, you use it to do something. Leyla's only six, but already she handles a bicycle well. On a farm everyone has to know how to handle a gun.

verb If you handle a person or situation, you control or manage them. I'll get him to agreeit's just a question of handling him right. Let her handle this her own way. I'd taken on more than I could handle.
adjective If something is handmade, it has been made by hand and not with a machine. They showed us some beautiful handmade rugs.
noun A handout is something such as food, clothing or money that is given free to poor people. They were reluctant to accept handouts from charities.
noun A handout is a sheet of information given out to the audience at a talk or lecture. Has everyone got a copy of both the handouts?

noun When you give someone a handshake, you grasp their right hand in yours and gently squeeze it or shake it for a moment. You do this as a greeting or as a formal sign of agreement. We all exchanged handshakes around the table. They sealed the deal with a handshake. With him a handshake is as binding as a written contract.
adjective If someone is handsome, they are good-looking and attractive. This word is usually used to describe men. Daniel grew into a handsome youth.

adjective If something is handsome, it is large in amount or generous. The company made a handsome profit last year. She made a handsome donation. It was very handsome of them to let us keep the money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb handsomely He was handsomely rewarded for his efforts.

form.definition: adjective In a hands-on activity you do things yourself to get practical experience of them instead of just learning about them from lectures or textbooks. A good computer course should include plenty of hands-on experience. The science museum had many hands-on exhibits.

noun Someone's handwriting is the characteristic way they form the letters and words when they write by hand. His handwriting was hard to read. I recognised the handwriting on the envelope. The notebooks were filled with her neat handwriting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective handwritten We received a handwritten invitation.

dictionary.entry:
handy`hAndi:handierhandiest 1a adjective If something is handy, it is useful or helpful. This gardening book is very handy to have. It was handy that she was able to come so quickly. I know a handy way of getting the lids off jars. b adjective If something is handy, it is nearby and convenient. The house is well situated and handy for schools and transport. Have you got a pen handy? I like to keep a few meals handy in the
adjective If someone is handy, they are skilled at using their hands, especially in doing odd jobs around the home. It's worth learning how to be handy with tools.
come in handy If something comes in handy, it is useful at one time or another. The road map came in handy when we got lost in the city.

form.definition: verb When something hangs, it is attached or fixed to something at the top and dangles free at the bottom. A mass of balloons hung from the ceiling. His broken arm hung limply. The bats hang upside down from the branches. I hung my coat on the hook.

verb To hang someone is to kill them by tying a rope around their neck and making their body hang in the air. She was sentenced to be hanged. He was so ashamed that he hanged himself. The mob hanged the suspected criminal from a tree.

get the hang of something If you get the hang of something, you come to understand it and be able to do it. If you follow the instructions you'll soon get the hang of it. I just can't get the hang of how to serve the ball.

hang around If you hang around, you spend time somewhere without doing anything in particular. The cinema had closed but there were still people hanging around. Why don't you go out instead of hanging around the house all day? She hangs around with a disreputable bunch.
hang on (a) If you hang on to something, you hold it tightly. Hang on to your hat or it'll blow away. Hang on there, we're moving off!
(b) If you hang on to something, you try to keep it as it was. You've got a good jobyou ought to hang on to it. There's no point hanging on when the relationship's over.
(c) If you tell someone to hang on, you're asking them to wait a minute or to stop what they're doing. Hang on! I'll just get a piece of paper. Hang on! That's the wrong way to do it.
hang out (a) If you hang out clothes that have been washed, you peg them to a washing line so that they can dry.
(b) If something hangs out of somewhere, it sticks out of it and dangles. His shirt was hanging out of his trousers.
(c) In informal language, if you say that you hang out somewhere, you mean that you often spend your leisure time there. Spike likes to hang out at the beach.
hang up (a) If you hang something up, you place it on something such as a hook or rail so that it is held up. I came in and hung up my coat behind the door.
(b) When you hang up after a telephone call, you put the receiver back in its place. Listen to what I have to say before you hang up on me.
noun A hangar is a large shed in which aircraft are kept. The plane was safe in the hangar when the storm hit.
noun A hanger is a curved piece of plastic, wood or wire, with a hook, for hanging up clothes.
noun A hang-glider is like a large kite. It has a frame you hang on to and it can carry you through the air in the wind.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hang-gliding

form.definition: noun A hangover is the sick feeling you get after drinking too much alcohol. Angus had a bad hangover when he woke after his party.
noun A hang-up is something that always worries you or makes you feel anxious. Gerry had a hang-up about his crooked nose.
noun Hankie is an informal short form of handkerchief. She started crying again and reached for a hanky.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is hanky (plural .

form.definition: adjective If something is haphazard, it is not neatly planned or organised. The trees grew in haphazard clumps. She's a bit haphazard about ringingsometimes there can be silence for weeks.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb haphazardly

form.definition: verb When an event happens, it occurs or takes place. When did the accident happen? These big meetings happen twice a year. Something important must have happened.

verb If something happens, it occurs by accident or without being planned. It wasn't meant to be that way, it just happened. I happened to overhear her mention him. Drop in if you happen to be passing. Do you happen to have a pen on you?

verb If something happens to someone or something, they're affected by it, often in an unpleasant way. Did you hear what happened to Jane? She was in a car smash. What's happened to my glasses? I can't find them anywhere. Look what happened to the towels in the wash.
adjective If you are happy, you feel pleasure or satisfaction. I was really happy to see her again. It was the happiest day of my life. It was lovely to see their happy faces.
adjective If you are happy, you are satisfied with something. Are you happy with the result? I'm not very happy about the way he's been behaving.

adjective If you are happy to do something, you are willing to do it as a favour to someone. Muoi was happy to help Quang wash the car. 'Thank you.' 'That's OK, I'm happy to help.' ... WORD FAMILYadverb happily She smiled happily. I'll happily give you a lift.noun happiness We wished him happiness in his future life.
verb If someone harasses you, they keep annoying you or giving you a hard time. Stop harassing me! I'll give you my answer when I've decided.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun harassment

form.definition: noun A harbour is a sheltered part of the sea, by the coast, where boats can anchor and be protected from storms.
verb If you harbour someone, you shelter them or give them a place to hide. Police suspect that someone in the area is harbouring the escaped prisoner.
verb If you harbour something, you keep it somewhere hidden where it can continue to exist. Dirty garbage bins can harbour germs. He's harboured a grudge against me ever since.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is harbor.

form.definition: adjective If something is hard, it is solid and feels firm when you touch it. The opposite of this is soft. I like chocolates with hard centres. Her arm was swollen and hard.
adjective If something is hard, it is difficult to do. The opposite of this is easy. The test was really hard. His writing is hard to read. It was hard to hear him above the noise.
If something is hard, it is unpleasant and you do not enjoy it. Tam's been having a hard time lately. It was hard to leave our dogs behind when we went on holiday.
adjective If something is hard, it is done with physical effort. Digging gardens is hard work. The horse gave him a hard kick.

adverb If you do something hard, you put a lot of effort into it. I worked hard all day. I tried hard to make things better. Think hard before you make a decision. I hit the ball hard. Knock harder or they won't hear.
hard disk A hard disk is a magnetic storage device inside a computer. It has a much higher storage capacity than a floppy disk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb harden The bread will harden if you leave it exposed to the air.noun hardness noun See disk.

form.definition: adverb If you hardly do something, then you only just do it. You almost don't do it. I could hardly get the jumper over my head. I hardly noticed he was there. We hardly ever meet these days. There's hardly any left.

adverb If you say that something is hardly so, you expect the people you're addressing to agree with you that it isn't so. Funerals are hardly happy occasions. This is hardly the time for an argument.
noun If you suffer hardship, you experience serious problems such as poverty or sickness. She has many hardships to contend with.
noun Hardware is tools and building materials that you use to do jobs in the house and garden. Make sure you have the necessary hardware before you begin.
noun Hardware is all the physical devices which make up a computer system.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with software.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is hardy, they can endure tough conditions. You have to be pretty hardy to get through the army training. You'd do better with hardy native plants than imported varieties.
noun If you harm someone or something, you injure or damage them. Fortunately no-one was harmed in the accident. The incident harmed her reputation.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun harm The matter was cleared up with no harm done.adjective harmful Too much fat in your diet is harmful to your health.

form.definition: noun In music, harmony is the combination of notes and chords and how they sound when they are played together. This piece of music is written in three-part harmony.

noun If there is harmony between people or things, they are in agreement or they go well together. The change of directors restored harmony among the board members. I like the harmony of the blues and greens in the painting.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective harmonious adverb harmoniously

form.definition: noun A harness is a set of leather straps and metal pieces that fit around a horse's head and body so that it can be ridden or used to pull a vehicle. Sam unbuckled the harness from the mare.

noun A harness is a set of straps that fits around a person's body. It can be used to attach equipment to, or to hold a person in place for safety. Check the harness before you descend the cliff. I put Joe into the baby harness.
verb When you harness a natural force such as water, wind or sunlight, you put it to use to produce energy. There are many schemes that harness the power of water to generate electricity.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb harness The groom harnessed one of the ponies for me to ride.

form.definition: noun A harp is an upright stringed instrument which you pluck with your fingers.
harp on If you harp on about something, you keep talking about it. She does tend to harp on about her favourite hobby. OK, I know you're boredthere's no need to keep harping on about it.
noun A harpoon is a spear attached to a rope that can be thrown or fired from a gun to catch large fish or whales. The native fishermen were very accurate with the harpoon.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb harpoon

dictionary.entry:
harshha:Sharsherharshest 1a adjective If someone is harsh, they are severe and unkind in the way they behave towards someone else. The convicts received harsh treatment for their crimes. The critics were harsh in their criticism. Don't be too harsh with himhe's
adjective If something is harsh, it has a severe or damaging effect on something else. Don't use harsh detergents on this delicate fabric. The climate in the Australian desert is very harsh.
adjective If something is harsh, it is rough or scratchy when you touch it. I don't like those harsh synthetic fibres.
adjective If something is harsh, it is intense and unpleasant to hear or see. The harsh sound of the chain saws could be heard across the valley. They emerged blinking in the harsh light.
... WORD FAMILYadverb harshly noun harshness

form.definition: verb If you harvest grain, fruit or vegetables grown on a farm, you gather or pick them when they are ripe. The crop must be harvested before the rains come.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun harvest The wheat harvest was good this year.

form.definition: verb Has is the form of have used with 'he', 'she' or 'it' in the present tense.
noun Hash is a mixture of chopped, cooked food, especially meat, which is reheated for another meal. For dinner we had hash from yesterday's roast lamb.

make a hash of If you make a hash of something, you mess up what you're trying to do. You make a bad job of it. Linda was so nervous she made a hash of her maths exam. I really made a hash of putting the wardrobe together.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hash We had hashed beef the next day.

form.definition: verb If you hassle someone, you bother and annoy them, often because you keep urging them to do something. Ranlee's hassling me to repay the loan. Don't hassle meI'll come when I'm ready.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hassle It's a hassle to drive in the city, with so many one-way streets.

form.definition: noun Haste is acting quickly. It can be doing something quickly because of an urgent or dangerous situation, and it can also be doing something too soon without thinking about it carefully. They had clearly left in haste. There's no need for so much hastewe've plenty of time. He spoke angry words in haste.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb hastily She hastily pushed the letter under the other papers.adjective hasty (hastier, hastiest) He regretted his hasty decision. Don't be too hasty about deciding.

form.definition: noun A hat is a covering for the head. There are many different types of hats, with different shapes. You should wear a hat if you're going to be out in the sun.

at the drop of a hat If you do something at the drop of a hat, you do it very readily, without having to be persuaded. Robin will talk about her illness at the drop of a hat. I'd go to Bali on business at the drop of a hat.
keep something under your hat If you keep something under your hat, you keep it secret. Don't tell anyone about the job offerkeep it under your hat for the moment.

talk through your hat If you talk through your hat, you don't know much about the subject you're talking about, and so what you say is very foolish. Peter thinks he's an expert on politics but he's talking through his hat.
verb When a young bird, fish or insect hatches, it breaks out of the egg in which it has developed. The baby echidna is hatching out of its shell. The eggs are beginning to hatch.

noun A hatch is an opening in a floor, roof or wall through which a person or things can pass. Normally it is covered by something flat when it is not in use. The sailors hurried down the hatch when the whistle sounded. She climbed through the hatch into the loft. He passed the plates through the serving hatch.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hatchery (hatcheries) Fish hatcheries help to stock the inland rivers with fish.

form.definition: noun A hatchback is a type of car with a door at the back which opens upwards so that you can load things into the boot.
noun A hatchet is a small axe with a short handle.
bury the hatchet When people bury the hatchet, they agree to stop quarrelling with each other and become friendly again. They were willing to forget their differences and bury the hatchet.
verb If you hate someone or something, you dislike them very strongly. The neighbours hated each other. I hate ironing.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hate Fish is one of my real hates.noun hatred I found it hard to conceal my hatred of him.

form.definition: noun In sport, if you have three successes in a row in the same match, such as getting three wickets in cricket or making three goals in football, you score a hat-trick. He's about to bowl his third ball and is going for a hat-trick.
adjective If someone is haughty, they are very proud and regard other people with contempt.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb haughtily

form.definition: verb If you haul something, you use a lot of strength to pull or drag it. The fishermen hauled in their heavy catch. Elephants are used to haul logs in the jungle.
noun A haul is an amount of something gathered together, particularly illegal or stolen goods. The police discovered a drugs haul worth millions of dollars.
verb When a ghost haunts a place, it appears there many times. People say the spirit of the dead man haunts the house.
verb If something haunts you, it disturbs you and you cannot get it out of your mind. He was haunted by guilt for the rest of his life. The look Tess gave me haunts me still.
noun A haunt is a place where someone goes often to spend time. The local disco is a popular haunt of the town's young people. He wasn't to be found in any of his usual haunts.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective haunted He dared me to spend a night in the haunted house.adjective haunting The song had a haunting melody.adverb hauntingly She is hauntingly beautiful.

form.definition: verb Have is used as an auxiliary verb to form the present perfect and past perfect tenses. I haven't seen her all day. She hadn't been in long when the phone rang.
verb If you have something, you own it or it is closely associated with you. He has a farm out west. I have two brothers and three sisters. We have a park at the bottom of our street.
verb If something has something else, it includes it as part of itself. The house has four bedrooms. The book has illustrations. The mattress has lumps in it.
verb If someone or something has a certain quality, that is a characteristic of it. Sue has big feet. The plant has no flowers. Some people have no sense of humour!
verb If you have an experience, it happens to you. He had a wonderful time at the party. I had a lot of trouble finding the right house.
verb If you have a disease, you suffer from it. I have hay fever. How long have you had this pain? Many of the carriers have no symptoms.
verb If you have a talk, a swim, a lesson, and so on, you perform or take part in that activity. Be quiet, Tamsin's having a sleep. We had a successful conference.
verb If you have food or drink, you choose and consume it. What shall we have for dinner? I'll have a steak. He has milk in his tea, I'm going to have mine black.
verb When a woman has a baby, she gives birth to it. Lita's just had another baby boy.
verb If you have something done, you arrange for it to be done. They had the fireplace bricked up. When are you having the washing machine installed.
verb If you have something happen to you, you experience that thing happening. I had the car break down on me this morning. He had a lot of people congratulate him on his speech.
had better If you had better do something, you ought to do it. It would be a good idea to do it. He thought he had better water the garden after the hot day. You'd better be careful what you say.
have had In informal language, if you say you have had someone or something, you mean that you are fed up with them. I've had this jobI'm leaving next week.
have it in for If someone has it in for you, they deliberately make life difficult for you. Tom thinks the teacher has it in for him.
have it made If you have it made, you are clearly successful. Enrico has it made with his lovely family and a great job.

have it out If you have it out with someone, you thoroughly discuss your differing opinions. There was tension between them and it was time they had it out. I want to have it out with you about Sophie.
have on (a) If you have something on, you are wearing it. Tom looked smarthe had on his best suit.
(b) If you have something on you, you are carrying it with you in a pocket or handbag. She needed a handkerchief but didn't have one on her. I don't have any money on me.
(c) If you have something on, you have an arrangement or a plan to do something. Vanessa has a dinner date on tonight. Come round later, if you've nothing else on. What have you got on next month?
(d) If you have someone on, you play a trick on them by trying to make them believe something that is not true. Don't you believe ithe's just having you on.
have over If you have someone over, you invite them to your home. We had our neighbours over for a chat and some afternoon tea.
If you have to do something, it is necessary for you to do it. You must do it. You have to put the money in here. He had to run to catch the train. You don't have to do it if you don't want to.
noun A haven is a place of safety, shelter or rest. The guest house was a haven for weary travellers.
noun Havoc is damage and destruction on a large scale. The terrible bushfires caused much havoc.
play havoc with If something plays havoc with something, it throws it into disorder. The violent electrical storm played havoc with the traffic. The high wind played havoc with her new hairdo.
noun A hawk is a bird of prey that catches and eats small animals. It has sharp claws and good eyesight. The hawk swooped down on the mouse and carried it off in its claws.
verb If you hawk something, you try to sell it to people on the street or by going to their homes. I answered the door to a man hawking his paintings.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hawker I bought some cheap souvenirs from a hawker.

form.definition: noun Hay is dried cut grass that is used to feed animals. The drought was so severe that the farmers had to feed hay to their cattle.
noun Hay fever is an allergy caused by pollen or dust. It causes inflammation of the nose, eyes and throat. Sylvia suffers badly from hay fever during spring.

adjective If something goes haywire, it becomes confused and doesn't work in the way it's supposed to. The buses and trains are all running latethe system has gone haywire. I pressed the wrong key and suddenly the program went haywire.
noun A hazard is something that is likely to be dangerous. Heavy traffic is a hazard to pedestrians. The asbestos in these buildings is a major health hazard.

verb In rather formal language, if you say you hazard a guess, you mean that you risk making it even though you aren't sure that it's right. I couldn't hazard a guess why he did such a nasty thing. Why don't you do it like this, if I may hazard a suggestion?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hazardous The explorers set out on the hazardous journey across the desert.

form.definition: noun A haze in the air makes things blurred to look at. It can be caused by smoke, dust or hot air rising from the ground. The car left behind a haze of dust as it sped along the dirt road. It was hard to see through the blue haze of smoke.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hazy (hazier, haziest) My memory of the event is a bit hazy.

form.definition: noun A hazel is a type of tree which produces nuts that you can eat.
noun Hazel is a light brown colour. ... WORD FAMILYadjective hazel I bought a box of hazel nuts. Ann has red hair and hazel eyes.
pronoun He is used to refer to a male person or animal that has already been mentioned. 'Is Bill at home?' 'No, he went for a walk.' I asked my doctor, and he was very helpful.
noun Your head is the top part of your body that is joined to your trunk by your neck. Brian was hit on the head with a cricket ball. She nodded her head in agreement.
b noun An animal's head is a similar front part of its body which contains organs for sensing things and usually the brain.

noun You can talk about your head when you mean your brain or mind. I don't need a calculatorI can do the sum in my head. He couldn't get the thought out of his head. She suddenly took it into her head to travel around the world.

noun The head of something is the top, front or most important part of it. He fell from the head of the stairs right to the bottom. The captain stood at the head of the line, with the rest of the team behind her. Dad always sits at the head of the table.
noun The head of a group or organisation is the person who leads or is in charge of it. There has been a big meeting of Asian government heads in Jakarta.

noun When you are counting animals or people, you can use the word head for each one of the group. So, if you say '$10 a head' you mean $10 each. The farmer has 1000 head of sheep for sale. Let's all put in $10 a head, to buy a combined present.

noun The head of a coin is the side with a picture of someone's head on it. The opposite of this is tail. Both words are usually used in the plural. 'Let's toss a coin to see who goes first. Heads or tails?' 'Tails.' 'No, it's headsI'll start.'
verb If you head a queue or a procession, you are at the front of it. A police escort will head the convoy down the main street.
verb If you head a group or organisation, you lead it or are in charge of it. I've just got a promotionnow I'm heading the computer department.

verb If you head a piece of paper or some writing with certain words, you put those words at the top, often as a title to explain what follows. You should head the letter with your own address and the address of the person you're writing to. The article was headed 'Fresh war danger in Gulf'.
verb If you head or are headed somewhere, you go or move in that direction. I was heading home when the rain started. 'Where are you going for your holidays?' 'We'll head for the beach somewhere.'
come to a head If something comes to a head, it reaches a crisis or a stage where you have to deal with it. The unrest came to a head when fighting broke out in the village square.
go to your head (a) If alcohol goes to your head, you become drunk, often more quickly than normal. The wine had gone to her head and she felt she was going to faint.
(b) If compliments or success go to your head, they cause you to become too confident and pleased with yourself. Just because you won the prize, don't let it go to your head!
head off If you head someone or something off, you make them go in a different direction. The goats are out! Head them off before they get into the vegetable garden.
keep your head down If you keep your head down, you try to avoid attention and stay out of trouble. If you're smart you'll keep your head down till the inquiry's over.
not make head nor tail of If you can't make head nor tail of something, you cannot work it out or understand it at all. I can't make head nor tail of these complicated instructions.

off the top of your head If you say something off the top of your head, you say it without thinking carefully about it or without having time to prepare it. Donald had to make the speech off the top of his head. Off the top of my head, I'd say we should finish by about July.
over your head If something is over your head, it is too difficult for you to understand. The lecture on nuclear physics went right over their heads.
put your heads together When people put their heads together, they try to think things out as a group. Let's put our heads together and see if we can come up with a solution to the problem.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective head Ted is our head sales representative.adjective headed He wrote on headed paper giving the company's name and address.

form.definition: noun A headache is a feeling of pain in the head. That noise is awfulit's giving me a headache.
noun In informal language, a headache is a problem that someone experiences. The washing machine keeps breaking downit's a real headache.
noun A heading is the title of a piece of writing, written at the top. We found the information under the heading 'Birds of prey'.
noun A headland is a piece of high land which juts out into the sea at the end of a beach. There is a good view of the beach and town from the headland.
noun A vehicle's headlights are the lamps at the left and right of its front which light up the road in the dark. Turn on your headlights as we go through the tunnel.
noun A headline is the words printed in large letters at the top of a story or article in a newspaper or magazine. 'RAIL STRIKE CHAOS' was the headline in the afternoon paper.
noun The headlines on a news broadcast are short summaries of the most important events. Let's turn on the radio and catch the news headlines.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb headline

form.definition: adverb When things meet head-on, they come together front first, usually with a lot of force. The cars crashed head-on and both drivers were killed.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective head-on I had a head-on confrontation with my boss today.

dictionary.entry:
headquarters`hEdkw@:t@z, hEd`kw@:t@z (plural form\optima0\headquarters
noun The headquarters of an organisation is the central place or office from which it is controlled. No time was wasted in setting up a headquarters for the distribution of aid to the refugees. The company's regional headquarters is in Singapore.
... AN ABBREVIATIONfor this is HQ.

form.definition: noun A head start is something that gives you an advantage over other people in a competitive situation. I want to give my children a good education so they have a head start in life.

noun A headstone is a slab of stone that is placed upright in the ground at the head of someone's grave. It is engraved with their name and the dates when they were born and died, and often a message from their relatives. Vandals had smashed and defaced several of the headstones in the cemetery.
adjective If someone is headstrong, they are determined to do what they want, and in their own way. You can't give Danica any adviceshe's too headstrong.
noun A headteacher is the teacher who is in charge of a school.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with principal.

form.definition: noun If you make headway, you move forward or get closer to achieving something. We made little headway in the heavy traffic. Have you made any headway with your project?
noun A headwind is a wind that blows in the opposite direction to the way you are travelling, and slows you down. The plane arrived late because of a strong headwind.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is tailwind.

form.definition: verb When a part of your body that has been injured heals, it becomes well and normal again. If you keep that cut clean it will heal quickly. The broken arm will take six weeks to heal.
noun Your health is your physical and mental condition. She's run down and in poor health. I enjoy excellent health. How's your wife's health these days?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective healthy (healthier, healthiest) I'm a pretty healthy person. It's important to eat a healthy diet.adverb healthily You should try to eat more healthily and get more exercise.

form.definition: noun A heap is a pile of things placed on top of one another in an untidy way. The heap of books on the desk made the room look messy. There's a heap of rubbish in the backyard.
noun In informal language, a heap of something or heaps of it means a large quantity. I've got a whole heap of work to do. Don't hurry, there's heaps of time. She must earn heaps of money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb heap Robert heaped his plate full of ice-cream.

form.definition: verb If you hear something, you are aware of a sound. 'What's that noise?' 'I can't hear anything.' Speak up, I can't hear you. I heard a knock at the door. Grandfather can't hear very well.

verb If you hear that something is so, you are told or get information about it. I hear there's going to be a bus strike next week. I'm very pleased to meet youI've heard so much about you from Chris. Have you heard the latest? Vicky's getting married.

have heard of If you have heard of someone or something, you are aware they exist. I've heard of the Ellora caves in India but I've never been there. Who is this Alan Cameron? I've never heard of him.
form.note: ... BE CAREFULwith the pronunciation of the past .

form.definition: hear, hear! You say hear, hear! to show that you agree with what someone is saying and support them. 'We're all pretty fed up with your attitude.' 'Hear, hear!'
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See hearing.

form.definition: noun Your hearing is your ability to hear sounds. Our grandmother's beginning to lose her hearing.

noun Someone's hearing is the range or distance within which they can hear something. Now that we are out of Marco's hearing, I want to ask your adviceI'm very worried about him. Soon the train faded from our hearing.
noun A hearing is a session of an official inquiry or investigation. Hearings before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are fairly formal and usually in public.
noun A hearing aid is a device which helps people to hear better if they are slightly deaf. Usually it is a small piece of electronic equipment worn in or behind the ear.
noun Hearsay is information that you have been told but which you don't have direct knowledge of. I thought that Julie was going to be the new supervisorbut that's only hearsay.
noun A hearse is the special vehicle used at a funeral to carry the coffin. A long procession of cars followed the hearse to the cemetery.
noun Your heart is the organ that pumps blood through your body. Stuart could feel his heart thumping after the sudden fright.

noun The heart is also the centre of your emotions and feelings. She has a kind heart. He may seem grumpy, but his heart's in the right place. My head says 'yes' to this new job overseas, by my heart says 'no'. It broke my heart to leave.
noun The heart of something is its centre or middle part. In the heart of the ancient city is a monastery. We flew across the dead heart of Australia.

noun The heart of something is its most important part. Let's get straight to the heart of the problem. The heart of the matter is you don't love him any more. This decision strikes at the heart of the funding of community services.

by heart If you know something by heart, you remember it exactly. I don't need the musicI know it by heart. When I was at school we had to learn a lot of poetry by heart. I use that train line so often that I know all the stops by heart.

change of heart If you have a change of heart, you change your opinion or the way you feel about something. Hasan's had a change of hearthe's not going to sell the car after all. The offer's open if you have a change of heart. I've had a change of heart towards hershe's not so bad.

heart attack If you have a heart attack, your heart suddenly stops working properly. The old man had died from a heart attack during the night. I nearly had a heart attack when I found out what she'd done.
hearts One of the four suits in a pack of playing cards is called hearts. The cards in this suit are marked with red heart-shaped signs.

lose heart If you lose heart, you become discouraged or less interested in something. Don't lose heartbusiness is sure to improve soon. I'm beginning to lose heart about my prospects of finding a job. They've rather lost heart in the project.
set your heart on something If you set your heart on something, you want it very much and will try to get it. Yanica's set her heart on a new car and she's saving hard.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See cardiac.

form.definition: noun Heartache is deep and lasting sadness or sorrow. The whole experience has brought me nothing but heartache.

noun Heartbreak is sudden and terrible sadness or disappointment. The news report showed the burnt-out house and the heartbreak on the faces of the family left homeless. I don't want to let myself in for another heartbreak.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective heartbreaking She told a heartbreaking tale of all that she'd endured.adjective heartbroken I was heartbroken when she left me.

form.definition: noun Heartburn is a feeling of burning in the chest that you get when your stomach cannot easily digest the food you've eaten. The rich fatty meal gave him heartburn.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis word with indigestion.

form.definition: verb If something heartens someone, it encourages them. It makes them feel more happy and cheerful. Ellie was heartened by her good exam results.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective heartening Their warm welcome was very heartening.

form.definition: adjective If someone is heartless, they are unkind and don't show any feelings. They don't seem to feel bad when they hurt or upset other people. How could he be so heartless as to leave her with a week-old baby?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb heartlessly She heartlessly rejected his appeal.

form.definition: adjective If someone is hearty, they are very cheerful and outgoing. They are not at all shy. She was a large, hearty woman. He gave a hearty laugh.
adjective A hearty meal is large and satisfying. Make sure you eat a hearty breakfast before our bushwalk.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb heartily You are heartily welcome. I heartily agree with your decision.

form.definition: noun Heat is being hot, or how hot something is. The fire's nearly gone out but there's still some heat in the coals. When it boils, turn down the heat. Run cold water over the burn to take the heat out of it.
noun The heat is hot weather. I was glad to get indoors out of the heat. I really feel the heat in summerI much prefer the winters.

noun Heat is intense feeling or strong excitement. He responded to the accusation with some heat. In the heat of the moment I spoke too hastily. Alberto tried to take the heat out of the argument by proposing a compromise.

noun In sport, a heat is one of several races at the beginning of a competition. The competitors who do best in the heats are chosen to take part in the final. There will be four heats for the 100 metres men's sprint.
verb When you heat something or heat it up, you make it warmer or hot. The metal is heated until it becomes soft. I heated up a pie in the microwave.
If something heats or heats up, it becomes warmer or hot. The soup is just heating nowit'll be ready soon. October already, and it's really beginning to heat up.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective heated We had a heated discussion about it. He was heated in his denial.adverb heatedly noun heating We've got oil heating in our house.

form.definition: noun A heater is a device that is used to warm the air in a room or to heat water.
noun A heatwave is a period of very hot weather. The city is experiencing its worst heatwave in ten years.
verb If you heave something, you use a lot of effort to move it because it is heavy and usually awkward. The men heaved the wardrobe onto the truck.

verb In informal language, if you say you heave something, you mean that you throw it or put it somewhere casually. The vandals heaved a brick through the shop window. 'I can't get this thing to work.' 'Heave it over hereI'll have a look at it.'
verb If something heaves, it moves up and down in a fairly slow and rhythmical way. The waves heaved, and the small boat was tossed about. His chest heaved as he lay on his back breathing heavily.
verb If you heave, you suddenly feel as if you are going to vomit. The foul smell was so strong it made Fiona heave.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun heave She gave a heave on the rope and it began to move.

form.definition: noun Heaven is the place where God lives and where good people go when they die.
noun Heaven is a place or state of great happiness. When I'm with you I'm in heaven. It's heaven just to be able to sit and relax.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with hell.

form.definition: heavens! If you say heavens!, you are expressing mild surprise. Heavens! What have you done to yourself? Oh heavens! Is that the time?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective heavenly She made the most heavenly pavlova.

form.definition: adjective If something is heavy, it weighs a lot. It is hard to move or lift. The opposite of this is light. The dresser's too heavy for me to shift. My head felt heavy and I wanted to go to sleep.
adjective If something is heavy, it is intense or concentrated in amount. We were delayed by heavy traffic on the roads. Sheena used to be a heavy smoker.
adjective If something is heavy, it is demanding and requires a lot of effort. Robert had a long and heavy day at the office. Building houses is heavy work.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb heavily She fell heavily and broke her arm. I don't like my food too heavily spiced.noun heaviness I felt a great heaviness come over me.

form.definition: verb If you heckle someone who is making a speech, you interrupt them with shouted comments. One radical group continually heckled the Liberal candidate.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun heckler Eventually the security guards put the heckler out of the room.

form.definition: noun A hectare is a metric unit for measuring the area of land. It equals 10 000 square metres. The local council has set aside two hectares of bush for a new reserve.
adjective If something is hectic, it is very busy and full of excitement or pressure. Everything has happened at onceit's been a hectic week. I was exhausted by all the hectic travel.[qr

dictionary.entry:
hedgehEdZ
noun A hedge is a barrier made from small shrubs or trees planted close together in a row. The hedges around the house were neatly trimmed.
verb If you hedge, you avoid giving a direct answer or making a decision. Stop hedgingjust tell me whether you can do it or not.

form.definition: noun Your heel is the back part of your foot below the ankle. These new shoes have given me blisters on my heels.
noun The heel of a sock or stocking is the part that covers the heel of the foot. These socks are beginning to wear through at the heels.
noun The heel of a shoe is the raised part at the back attached to the sole. I tripped on a grating and ripped the heel off my shoe. She always wears high heels to make herself look taller.
dig your heels in If you dig your heels in, you stubbornly refuse to do what other people want you to do. Bruce dug his heels in and said he was going to do it, no matter what we thought.
down at heel If someone is down at heel, they look shabby and untidy. Nancy's clothes were dirty and needed mendingshe looked very down at heel.
adjective If someone is hefty, they are big, heavy and muscular. Bill's a hefty young man and should be able to help us shift the fridge.
adjective If something is hefty, it is large or substantial. She served us each a hefty slice of cake. I had to pay a hefty price for the painting.
noun A heifer is a young female cow.

noun The height of something is the distance from the bottom to the top. It is how high or tall it is. What is the height of that cupboard? You are overweight for someone of your height. b noun The height of something is the distance between it and the ground. At what height is the plane flying? The strong wind lifted the kite to a great height.

noun The height of something is the time at which it is most intense or active. At the height of the festival the fireworks were let off. The industry was worth several millions of dollars at its height.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb See heighten.

form.definition: verb If something heightens, or you heighten something, it increases in intensity. The competition was very closethe excitement heightened with every race. You need to heighten the contrast in this photo.
noun Your heirs are the people who inherit your property when you die.

noun An heirloom is some object, such as a painting or piece of jewellery, that is handed down in a family from one generation to the next. Some heirlooms are valuable, some have only sentimental value.
verb Held is the past tense and past participle of hold.
noun A helicopter is an aircraft that has no wings but has blades that turn around at the top. It takes off and lands vertically.
noun A heliport is a place where helicopter flights can begin and end. The flat roof of the building was being used as a heliport.
noun Hell is the place where the Devil lives and where bad people go when they die.
noun Hell is a place or state of misery or unpleasantness. It's hell in this office with no airconditioning. Since our split I've been to hell and back.

noun In informal language, hell is also used as an exclamation of annoyance or to emphasise something. Oh hell! I've left my umbrella on the train. Gina worked like hell to finish the job before dark. What the hell do you think you're doing?

a hell of a In informal language, a hell of a can be used to emphasise something. You'll need a hell of a lot of money to furnish this big new house. We had a hell of a good time at the party. They've got a hell of a nerve expecting me to pay for it.

for the hell of it If you do something for the hell of it, you do it for fun rather than for a particular reason. I decided to go along too, just for the hell of it. I haven't driven all night to get here just for the hell of it, you know.

go to hell If you tell someone to go to hell, you are telling them very rudely that you don't want to have anything to do with them. 'Can I borrow your car, Kumi?' 'Go to hell!' The whole lot of them can go to hell as far as I'm concerned.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hellish We had a hellish journey to Bangkok.

form.definition: interjection You use hello to greet someone informally or when you answer the telephone. Hello, Aunt Martha! It's nice to see you again. Hello, this is John Smith speaking.

say hello If you say hello to someone, you greet them. You may not use the actual word hello but you could say something else such as 'good day'. She barely looked up when I said hello to her. Say hello to your mother for me, will you?
noun The helm is the wheel that is used to steer a boat or ship. The captain went to take the helm.
at the helm If someone is at the helm, they are in charge. The boss is away, so I'm at the helm today.

noun A helmet is a hard hat which protects your head and is worn by people such as fire fighters, miners, soldiers, cyclists and motorbike riders. It is illegal to ride a bicycle on the streets without a helmet.

verb When you help someone, you assist them and make it easier for them to do something. Can you help me do the gardening? I helped Helen with her homework. Ali helped the old lady off the train. Can I do anything to help? It helped a lot that she was so friendly.

verb If you cannot help the way you think or act, you cannot control it or stop it from happening. I couldn't help spilling my drinkToby bumped my arm. I couldn't help but notice her. I keep laughing, I just can't help it. Don't scratch the bites more than you can help.
noun Help is assistance. Would you like some help with the decorating? Louisa needs extra help with her reading.
noun If someone or something is a help, they give assistance or are useful. Thanks for your adviceyou've been a great help. It's a big help having a washing machine.

help yourself If you help yourself to something, you take it for yourself or you serve yourself. I'll put the badges on the table so people can help themselves. Help yourself to more wine. 'May I have one of these?' 'Help yourself.' He'd been helping himself to company funds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun helper We still need some more helpers for the fair next week.adjective helpful The book contains helpful details. She wasn't very helpful when I asked.

form.definition: noun A helping of food is a portion or a serving of it. Just a small helping of pasta, pleaseI'm on a diet. Would anyone like a second helping?

adjective If a person or animal is helpless, they are not able to defend or look after themselves. I might have fought off one mugger, but I was helpless against the four of them. Try and sort it out on your owndon't be so helpless.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb helplessly I looked on helplessly as she was swept away.noun helplessness

form.definition: verb If you hem a piece of cloth or a garment, you turn back the edge of it and sew it down. You'll have to hem the ends to stop them from fraying.

hem in If you hem something in, you surround or enclose it completely so that it cannot move. Thousands of protesters on the streets hemmed in the army tanks. I'm beginning to feel hemmed in by this jobit's time for a change.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hem The skirt's too longI'll have to take up the hem.

form.definition: noun The two hemispheres of the earth are the parts above and below the equator. Australia is in the southern hemisphere; Europe is in the northern hemisphere. This is the tallest building in the southern hemisphere.
noun The hemline of a skirt or dress is its bottom edge. This season hemlines are well below the knee.
noun Hemp is a plant which produces the drug marijuana and fibres that are used to make rope and coarse cloth.
noun A hen is a female chicken, especially one that is kept to lay eggs.
conjunction In formal language, hence is used to indicate a reason for something. Monday is a public holiday, hence there will be no classes. The house was burgled, hence the broken window.
adverb In formal language, hence means 'from here' or 'from now'. The river is still a long way hence. Where do you see yourself ten years hence?
adverb In formal language, henceforth means 'from now on'. All payments must henceforth be made in cash.
noun Hepatitis is a serious disease which causes inflammation of the liver. There are several different types of hepatitis, caused by different viruses.

pronoun Her is the form of she that you use as the object of a verb or after a preposition. I really hated her for saying that. The child gave her a big smile. There's Karen, but who's that person with her?
adjective You use her to indicate that something belongs to a female person who has been mentioned. Lisa brought her friend to the party.

verb In formal language, if something heralds an event, it announces or indicates that it is beginning or will happen in the future. The first rays of light in the sky heralded the dawn of a new day. Does the growth in the economy herald a new round of interest rate rises?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun herald Is this announcement the herald of a major change in policy?

form.definition: noun A herb is a plant whose different parts are used to add flavour to foods or to make medicines. The salad was garnished with fresh, chopped herbs. The Chinese make a lot of use of medicinal herbs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective herbal We drank some refreshing herbal tea.noun herbalist The herbalist mixed up a medicine to treat Richard's bronchitis.

form.definition: noun A herd is a large group of animals that move together. ...a herd of cattle.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb herd He spent his youth herding cattle.

form.definition: adverb Here means in or at this place or spot. Here in Brisbane the winters are very mild. Let's wait here for a while. What's this handle here? 'Where does it hurt?' 'Here.' Let me introduce myself and tell you why I'm here.
adverb Here means to or towards this place or spot. Come here, so I can pin the badge on you. Angie came here five years ago and has stayed ever since.
adverb Here also means at this point in a sequence of events. The music starts off at a lively pace till the second movement. Here the mood changes.
interjection You can use here at the beginning of a remark, to attract someone's attention. Here, let me do it. Here, what do you think you're playing at?

here and there Here and there means in several scattered places. In the valley below you could see smoke rising here and there from chimneys. She leaves her clothes here and there on the floor. Here and there the lettering was still visible.

here goes You say here goes when you are about to try doing something and are not sure whether it will work. I haven't ridden a bicycle for many years, but here goes! Here goes, turn the electricity on and we'll see if it's mended.
here's to You say here's to when you are offering a toast. Here's to your future success! Here's to Anita on her birthday!
here we are If you are talking to someone while you look for something, when you find it you often say here we are. I know it's here somewhere. Yes, here we are, right at the back of the drawer.

8 here we go again You say here we go again when something that you don't enjoy starts happening again. Here we go againwe're going to hear all about his difficult childhood. As the car shuddered to a halt, I thought 'Oh no, here we go again'.
here you are You often say here you are when you hand something to someone. 'I'd like a box of matches.' 'Here you are, that'll be fifty cents, please.'

neither here nor there If something is neither here nor there, it is not important or relevant. Whether she meant to or not is neither here not therethe fact is she's caused a great deal of inconvenience.
noun Heredity is the process by which genetic traits are passed down from one generation to the next. Two of Nerida's brothers have red hairit's a trait of heredity in her family.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hereditary Haemophilia is a hereditary disease.

form.definition: noun Heresy is a belief or opinion contrary to what is officially accepted by a religion or group. It seems to be heresy even to suggest another way of approaching the issue.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun heretic adjective heretical

form.definition: noun Your heritage is a set of customs or traditions that is passed down to you by your family or community. Aborigines are trying to preserve an indigenous cultural heritage which goes back many thousands of years.
noun A country's heritage is the things that remain as reminders of its history. He accused property developers of destroying the city's heritage.
noun A hermit is someone who lives alone and keeps away from society. Come to the partydon't be a hermit!

noun If you have a hernia, part of your intestines sticks out through a hole inside the abdomen, causing a bulge that can be painful. If you lift heavy things the wrong way you can give yourself a hernia.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is rupture.

form.definition: noun A hero is someone who has done something brave or impressive. A service was held to commemorate the heroes of the last war. She came in to work even though she was really sickshe's a hero.
noun The hero of a novel or movie is the most important character. The part of the hero was played by an unknown actor.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective heroic It was really heroic of you to stay up all night to finish the job.noun heroism She received a medal for her heroism in rescuing the children from the fire.

form.definition: noun Heroin is an illegal, addictive drug made from morphine.
noun Heroine is sometimes used as the female form of the word hero.
noun Herpes is a viral infection of the skin that causes blisters. There are several different types of herpes.

pronoun Hers is used to refer to something that belongs to a female person who has been mentioned. Carrie brought her umbrella, but Stella forgot hers. That son of hers is a real larrikin. Are you a relative of hers?
pronoun Herself is the reflexive form of she. Hannah cursed herself for forgetting. The old lady can't feed herself.
pronoun Herself is used to emphasise the female person you are talking about. She's definitely leaving, she told me so herself.
pronoun If a female person is not herself, she is not in her normal state of mind or health. Norma needs a holidayshe hasn't been herself lately.
verb If you hesitate, you pause for a moment because you are not certain what to say or do. She hesitated before answering. I hesitated at the door, then took a deep breath and walked in.

verb If you hesitate to do something, you are reluctant to do it because you are not sure if it is appropriate. If you require any further information, please do not hesitate to contact me again. I hesitated to ask after her father as I knew he'd been very ill.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hesitant He was rather hesitant in his replies.adverb hesitantly The baby hesitantly took a step forwards.noun hesitation She volunteered without a moment's hesitation.

form.definition: adjective Someone who is heterosexual is sexually attracted to people of the opposite sex.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is homosexual. ... WORD FAMILYnoun heterosexual noun heterosexuality

form.definition: verb If you hew something, you chop or carve it roughly. He had spent most of the day hewing wood. They hewed stone slabs from the rocks.
noun The heyday of something is the period when it is most successful or powerful. In the heyday of Bridget's modelling career, her face appeared in all the fashion magazines.
verb When animals hibernate, they sleep through the winter in a safe place.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hibernation The bears come out of hibernation in spring.

form.definition: verb When you hiccup, there is a sudden movement in your chest, over which you have no control. It causes you to take a quick breath and to produce a sharp sound. Someone hiccupped in the middle of the lecture.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGof this word is hiccough. ... WORD FAMILYnoun hiccup Give her a drink of waterit might stop her hiccups.

form.definition: verb Hidden is the past participle of hide.
verb If you hide, you keep yourself out of sight. Matthew thought he'd trick his mother so he hid behind the curtains. They escaped their pursuers by hiding in a ditch.
verb If you hide something, you put it somewhere where it can't be seen. You hope that it won't be found. I can't find my keyshave you hidden them?
verb If you hide facts or your feelings, you keep them secret. Esther managed to hide her surprise. There's something you've been hiding from me, isn't there.
noun The hide of an animal is its skin, especially when it is used to make leather. Several hides are needed to make a leather coat. His boots were made of cow hide.
have a hide If you say someone has a hide, you mean that they are bold and shameless. Alison's got a hide to ask for more money.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hiding We can't contact him anywherehe seems to have gone into hiding.

form.definition: noun A hideaway is a place where you go to get away from people. I'm going to retreat to my hideaway in the country this weekend.

adjective If something ishideous, it is very ugly and shocking. The heroes of the science-fiction movie did battle with hideous monsters. There were scenes of hideous suffering in the famine-stricken region. I look hideous in this dress. ... WORD FAMILYadverb hideously He's hideously ugly.

dictionary.entry: hierarchy`ha:I@ra:ki:hierarchies noun A hierarchy is a system where people or things are graded in order of importance. I'm slowly beginning to rise up the office hierarchy. ... WORD FAMILYadjective hierarchical The company has a very hierarchical structure.

form.definition: noun A hi-fi is a set of electronic equipment for playing recorded music with a very high quality of reproduction. Co-Van has spent a lot of money on his hi-fi.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hi-fi He's fanatical about getting the latest hi-fi equipment.

form.definition: adjective If something is high, it measures a large amount from bottom to top. It extends a long way off the ground. The opposite of this is low. Kosciusko is the highest mountain in Australia.
adjective If something is a certain measurement high, it is that distance from bottom to top. We've got a large tree in our yardit must be at least ten metres high. How high is that building?
adjective If something is high, it is far above ground level. The opposite of this is low. We went right up to the highest floor of the building.
adjective High also means great in amount or degree. The opposite of this is low. I'd love to buy that painting but the price is too high. The car took off at high speed.

adjective A high sound has a pitch that is characterised by rapid vibration of the sound wave. The opposite of this is low. The singers had trouble reaching the high notes of the song. Women's voices are generally higher than men's.
adjective If food is high, it is rotting and smells bad. That meat has gone offit's really high.
adjective In informal language, if you say someone gets high, you mean that they become drunk or are under the influence of drugs.
noun A high is a maximum amount or degree. The opposite of this is low. The temperature reached a high of 26 degrees today.
high and low If you search high and low for something, you look everywhere to try to find it. I can't find my glasses anywhereI've looked high and low.
high time If you say it's high time to do something, you mean it should have been done earlier and must definitely be done now. It's high time you bought some new shoesthose ones are quite shabby.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See height.

form.definition: noun A highbrow is someone who is interested in the arts and intellectual pursuits.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective highbrow She reads a lot of highbrow literature.

form.definition: noun The highland or highlands is a hilly or mountainous area of country.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective highland

form.definition: noun The highlight of an event is the most interesting, exciting or important part. The highlight of the celebrations was the fireworks display.
verb If you highlight something, you make it stand out and show that it is important. The low profits have highlighted the need to change our production methods.
noun A highligher is a brightly coloured pen that you use to mark something important. You can see the writing underneath.
adverb You use highly to emphasise an adjective. That's highly unlikely to happen. I was highly suspicious of his conduct.
adverb If you speak or think highly of someone, you have a good opinion of them. Emil was well known and well lovedeveryone spoke highly of him.
noun A high school is a school for children aged between 11 and 18. They go there when they have finished primary school.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is secondary school.

form.definition: noun The high season is the time of year when it is busiest and most expensive to travel or go on holidays. We'd save a lot of money if we didn't go on holidays during the high season.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is low season.

form.definition: noun A highway is a main road. It is usually wide and carries a lot of traffic between major towns and cities.
verb If someone hijacks a plane or vehicle, they seize it by using force and threats. They usually do it for political reasons. The rebels were sentenced to 20 years for hijacking an aircraft.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hijacker

form.definition: verb If you hike, you go for a long walk in the country, bush or mountains. Last weekend, we hiked for 10 km in the National Park.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is bushwalk. ... WORD FAMILYnoun hike Do you want to come on a hike next Sunday?noun hiker noun hiking
