form.definition: adjective If something is hilarious, it is very funny. His latest movie is a hilarious comedy. She told hilarious tales of her adventures.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb hilariously The whole thing was hilariously funny.noun hilarity His announcement was greeted with general hilarity.

form.definition: noun A hill is a raised area of land that occurs naturally. It is not as high as a mountain. The house on top of the hill had a lovely view.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hilly (hillier, hilliest) I live in a hilly district.

form.definition: noun The hilt is the handle of a sword or dagger. The knife was plunged into the victim's body up to the hilt.
pronoun Him is the form of he that you use as the object of a verb or after a preposition. I like him a lot. Did you give him the message? He became aware of someone looking at him.
pronoun Himself is the reflexive form of he. He had really got himself into a mess this time.
adjective The hind part of an animal is its back part. The horse was limpingits hind leg had been injured.

verb If someone or something hinders an event or action, they get in the way or make it more difficult for it to happen. Wet weather hindered the completion of the roadwork. We've been hindered by not having the right tools.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hindrance He didn't have the necessary experience and was more of a hindrance than a help.

form.definition: noun You have hindsight if you can see and understand the reasons for something after it has happened. In hindsight, Rasha shouldn't have invested all her money in the one company. With the benefit of hindsight, it's obvious that the plan was doomed to failure.
form.note: ... COMPAREthis with foresight.

form.definition: noun Hinduism is the main religion followed by people in India. Its followers believe in a number of gods and that after death your soul is reborn in another body.
noun A hinge is a joint which allows a door or lid to turn so that you can open and close it. Don't swing on the gateyou'll break the hinges!
hinge on If you say the outcome of an event hinges on something, you mean that it will be determined by it. Melissa's career hinges on her exam results.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hinge The flap is hinged at the side.

form.definition: noun A hint is a suggestion or indication you give someone in a roundabout way. You don't tell them directly, but you hope that they will guess from what you say. I know just what I want for ChristmasI'll have to drop some hints. Her letter contained some hints that she might be leaving soon.

noun A hint of a certain quality is a small amount of it which you might almost fail to notice. There was a hint of mockery in his voice. The soup is flavoured with pepper and a hint of garlic. She spoke without a hint of bitterness.
noun A hint is a piece of helpful advice. The magazine contains handy hints on cooking and gardening. I'll give you a hintit's easier if you hold it this way round.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hint She hinted that I'd offended her in some way.

form.definition: noun Your hip is the area at each side of your body that is below the waist and above the top of the legs. See the picture at body. She stood with her hands on her hips. He was shot through the hip. These exercises will slim your hips and thighs.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hip What's your hip measurement? It's in my hip pocket.

form.definition: verb If you hire something, you arrange to use it for a certain period in return for payment. Let's hire a boat for the day and go fishing on the lake.
verb If you hire someone, you arrange for them to do a job for you in return for payment. We've hired a babysitter to mind the children this evening.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hire They have equipment for sale and hire.

form.definition: noun If you buy something on hire-purchase, you are allowed to take delivery of it and then pay for it in instalments. Usually a deposit is required and interest is charged. This arrangement is now officially called a credit sale. We bought our fridge on hire-purchase. We paid $200 down and we have to pay another $100 a month for the next six months.
adjective You use his to show that something belongs to a male person who has been mentioned. He picked up his books and walked out.
pronoun His is used to refer to something that belongs to a male person. Carlos claimed that the book was his.
verb When something hisses, it makes a sound like a long 's' sound. The gas hissed as it escaped from the hole in the pipe.
verb When people hiss a speaker or performer, they make this sound to show that they don't like what is being said or done. The crowd hissed and jeered the politicians at the rally.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hiss

form.definition: adjective If something is historic, it is famous or important in history. Have you visited any of Sydney's historic houses?
adjective Historical things or events existed or occurred in the past. They are regarded as part of history. A historical fact is based on the study of history.
adjective Historical books or pictures deal with things that existed in the past.
noun If you study history, you study important events that have happened in the past. Anna is very interested in modern historyit's her favourite subject at school.
noun The history of someone or something is facts connected with their past. The doctor recorded my medical history. The convict prison at Port Arthur has a sad history.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun historian

form.definition: verb If you hit someone or something, you strike them with your hand or with an object. The kids were fighting and hitting each other. You have to hit the ball over the net.

verb When an object hits something, it collides with it with force. The ball hit the window and broke it. She was hit by a car and seriously injured. I hit my knee against the table. The bullet hit him in the shoulder.

verb In informal language, if you say someone or something hits a place or position, you mean that they reach or arrive at it. The Australian dollar hit a new high on the money market today. We finally hit the motel at midnight.
noun A hit is a blow or a stroke. Gerry took a hit at the ball but missed. The building was completely destroyedit had taken a direct hit from enemy guns.

noun If something or someone is a hit, it is very successful. It's years since I kept up with the latest rock hits. Carl is so nicehe was a real hit with all of us. The company badly needs to have a hit with this next launch.

hit it off If you hit it off with someone, you get on very well with them when you first meet them. You feel friendly towards each other. Darren and I hit it off at oncewe've got the same sense of humour. Lauren just couldn't hit it off with the new girl in the office.
hit on If you hit on an idea, you come up with it when you are thinking about a problem in a general way. Suddenly Malcolm hit on a good plan that would solve the problem.
hit hard If something hits someone hard, it makes them suffer a lot. The bad news hit her hard. Many small firms were hit hard by the recession.
hit the ceiling In informal language, if you say someone hits the ceiling, you mean they become very angry. Damian was afraid to tell the truthhe knew his father would hit the ceiling.
hit the road If you hit the road, you start or set out on a trip. It took ages to pack but we finally hit the road at about 10 o'clock.

adjective A hit-and-run accident occurs when a vehicle is involved in a road accident and the driver does not stop. This is a serious offence. Hit-and-run drivers can normally expect to have their licence cancelled.
verb If you hitch something to something else, you hook or fasten them together. More carriages were hitched onto the train at the junction.
verb When you hitch a ride, you get a lift in someone else's vehicle. Maria missed the bus and the only way to get to town was to hitch a lift.
noun A hitch is a small problem or a temporary delay. The performance went off without a hitch. A technical hitch interrupted the broadcast.
hitch up If you hitch up your trousers, you pull them up so that they fit properly around your waist. Tuck in your shirt and hitch up your trouserstry to look tidy!
verb If you hitchhike, you try to get a free ride in a passing vehicle by standing at the side of the road and signalling to drivers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hitchhiker noun hitchhiking

form.definition: adverb In formal language, hitherto means 'until now'. The results are better than we have hitherto experienced.
noun A hive is a wooden box made for bees to live in. On hot days you can smell the honey in the hives.
noun If you say a place is a hive of industry or a hive of activity, you mean that it is full of people working hard or bustling about. The early morning fruit market was a hive of activity.

hives Hives are an itchy red rash on your skin, caused by something you've touched or by food you've eaten that you're allergic to. I must get some lotion from the chemist to put on these itchy hives.
verb If you hoard something, you save up or collect as much of it as possible and store it in a safe place. Rumours of a distribution strike caused people to hoard provisions.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hoard She didn't trust banks, and kept a hoard of money in a wooden box.

form.definition: noun A hoarding is a high fence put around a site while building work is going on. I used to love peeping through the hoardings and staring down into the deep pits.
noun A hoarding is also a large board on which posters and advertisements are displayed.
adjective When your voice is hoarse, it sounds harsh and low, usually because you've got a cold or you've been shouting or talking too much. We were hoarse from barracking for our team.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hoarseness

form.definition: noun A hoax is a trick someone plays by making people believe something that isn't true. Generally it is done to cause trouble rather than as a joke. The bomb scare turned out to be a hoax. ... WORD FAMILYverb hoax When she didn't turn up, he realised that he'd been hoaxed.
verb If you hobble, you walk with difficulty, taking short limping steps, usually because your feet are sore or injured. I got blisters on my heels and had to hobble home.
noun A hobby is something that you enjoy doing in your spare time. Robert's favourite hobby is building model boats.
noun If someone is on their hobbyhorse, they are talking about their favourite subject with great enthusiasm. I hoped to leave early, but he got onto his hobbyhorse of diving.
noun Hockey is a game that is played by two teams on a field or on ice. The players use sticks with curved ends and long handles to try to hit a ball or a rubber disc into a goal.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hockey ...a hockey match. ...a hockey team.

form.definition: noun A hoe is a garden tool with a long handle attached to a small blade. You use it to loosen soil and remove weeds.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hoe

form.definition: noun A hog is a male pig.
verb If you hog something, you take or use more than your fair share of it. Don't hog the prawnsleave some for the rest of us. Daniel was hogging the sofa, so the rest of us had to sit on the floor.

go the whole hog If you go the whole hog, you do something completely and to its limit. Often this involves spending a lot of money to get the very best of something. Let's go the whole hog and have dinner out after the show.
verb When you hoist something, you raise or lift it, often with the help of some piece of apparatus. The containers were hoisted on board the ship. He hoisted himself onto the back of the truck.
verb When you hoist a flag, you raise it on a pole. The flag was hoisted at sunrise every morning.
noun A hoist is a machine or device for raising or lifting things.

verb If you hold something, you keep it in your hands or arms. You grasp it. You hold this end, Annie. Hold on to the rail as you go down. He held out the book to me. She held up the painting for us to see. Hold my hand while we cross the road.

verb If you hold something in a certain position, you keep it fixed or stationary like that. You do not allow it to move. We used ropes to hold the load on the truck. Hold the nail still while I hammer it in.
verb When something holds a particular amount, it has space for that amount. That is its capacity. The hall will hold 200 people.
verb If you hold a function, you organise it and make it happen. Let's hold a party for your birthday. The Sunday market is held in the village square.
verb If something holds, it stays unchanged. What I said last week no longer holdsthe circumstances have changed. If his luck holds at the casino he'll be rich.
noun The hold of a ship is the part below the deck that is used for transporting goods.
noun If someone has a hold on or over you, they are able to influence and control you, often because you are afraid of them. Richard was a bully and had a hold on the younger boys.
hold back (a) If you hold something back, you keep it in check or in reserve. Tasha managed to hold back her tears in spite of her disappointment. I held back $500 in case of emergencies.
(b) If you hold back information, you keep it secret. Seb knows more than he's sayingI'm sure he's holding something back from us.
hold it If you tell someone to hold it, you are telling them quite urgently or rudely to stop what they are doing. Hold ityou're doing it all wrong. Hold itjust where do you think you're going?
hold on If you ask someone to hold on, you want them to stop what they are doing or saying for a moment. Hold on, I need to get a pencil. Hold on, I didn't understand that last bit.
hold up (a) If you hold something up, you delay it. Hurry up and sit downyou're holding up the meeting. I'm waiting on a letterit must be held up in the mail.
(b) If you hold someone or something up, you rob them by threatening them with a gun. Two men carrying shotguns held up a bank and got away with thousands of dollars.
noun A hold-up is a delay. Quang should be home by nowthere's probably been a hold-up in the traffic.
noun A hold-up is an armed robbery. There was a hold-up at our bank yesterday and one of the tellers was wounded.
noun A hole is an opening through something flat. They squeezed through the hole in the fence. Mind your cigaretteI don't want it to burn holes in the carpet.
noun A hole is also a hollow or cavity in something solid. We dug a hole in the ground and buried the mouse. The trip made quite a hole in my savings.
noun In informal language, a hole is an unpleasant place to live. Surely you can find somewhere better to rent than this hole? The town where I grew up was a real holeI never want to go back there.
noun A holiday is a period of time when you have a rest from work, school or studies. We took a holiday in Fiji last year. What did you do on your holidays last summer?
noun A holiday is also a single day when you do not have to go to work. Australia Day is on 26th January, and it's a public holiday.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb holiday Their house was burgled while they were holidaying overseas.

form.definition: adjective If something is hollow, it has a hole inside it. It is not solid. She gave me a hollow chocolate egg. The birds were nesting in a hollow tree.
adjective If words or emotions are hollow, they are not sincere or they are of no practical help. Don't count on itthat was a hollow promise.

noun A hollow is a depression in something. Natasha lives in a damp hollow at the bottom of a hill. I was alarmed by her sunken eyes and the hollows in her cheeks. The legs of the bed had made hollows in the carpet.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hollow I hollowed the wood into a bowl.noun hollowness

form.definition: noun A holocaust is an enormous disaster when many people are killed. No-one wants to see a nuclear holocaust destroy the world.
noun A hologram is a picture made with a laser which appears to have three dimensions although the surface is flat.
noun A holster is a case for a pistol, worn on a belt around the waist.
adjective If something is holy, it relates to God or to a particular religion. This is one of the holiest days in the Christian calendar.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is sacred. ... WORD FAMILYnoun holiness

form.definition: noun Homage is great respect or honour that you show to a person or an ideal. On Anzac Day, Australians pay homage to their war heroes.
noun Your home is the unit or house where you live. My home is in the third block of units on the left.
noun Your home is also the town or country where you live or were born. I'm only here for a holidaymy home is New York. She left home when she got married. I decided to make a new home in Australia.
noun The place that animals or plants are native to is their home. Australia is the home of kangaroos and koalas.
noun A home is an institution where people who cannot look after themselves are cared for. My elderly aunt went into a nursing home. She was brought up in a children's home.
adverb If you are home, you are in the place where you live. Call round any time, I'll be home all day.
adverb If you come or go home, you return to the place where you live. I want to get home before it's dark.
at home (a) If you feel at home, you are at ease and not worried by the situation in which you find yourself. A good host makes her guests feel at home.
(b) If you are at home with something, you are familiar with it. You know all about it. This computer is just like mineI feel completely at home with it.
homemade Homemade food has been made in someone's home, rather than in a factory. Homemade jam tastes better than the mass-produced stuff.
noun Your homeland is the country where you were born.

adjective If you are homesick when you are away from your home, you feel sad because you miss your family, friends and familiar surroundings. When I first came to Australia I was dreadfully homesick, but I soon settled in.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun homesickness

form.definition: noun A homestead is the main house on a station or large farm.
noun Home unit is another word for flat, apartment or unit.
noun Homework is the work students have to do at home for the course they're studying. Kate went out after she'd finished her homework.

noun Homework is also the preparation you do before an activity such as a meeting or discussion, or before giving a report or speech. Oralie was able to answer all the questionsshe had done her homework well.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with housework.

form.definition: noun Homicide is the crime of killing someone. It includes both murder and manslaughter.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective homicidal When I found out what had happened, I was homicidal.

form.definition: noun Homoeopathy is a way of treating disease by giving very small doses of drugs which, if given in larger doses, would cause similar symptoms to those of the disease being treated.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is homeopathy. ... WORD FAMILYnoun homoeopath adjective homoeopathic

form.definition: adjective If something is homogeneous, it is made up of many parts that are all the same. Our social club is a fairly homogeneous group of people with similar interests.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb homogenise (<or> homogenize)

form.definition: adjective Someone who is homosexual is sexually attracted to people of the same sex as they are.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is heterosexual. ... WORD FAMILYnoun homosexual noun homosexuality

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is honest, you can trust them or rely on them. They will not deceive you or trick you. It's very honest of you to admit your mistake. Give me your honest opinion.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is dishonest. ... WORD FAMILYadverb honestly I'm sorry I hurt youI honestly didn't mean to.noun honesty In all honesty, I can't say I like him very much.

form.definition: noun Honey is the sticky, sweet food that bees make from flowers.
noun In informal language, you can call someone you are fond of honey. What time will you be home, honey?[qr

dictionary.entry:
honeycomb`hV ni:k@Um
noun A honeycomb is the wax structure that bees make in their hive to store honey, pollen and eggs. It is made up of small six-sided cells.

form.definition: noun A honeymoon is a holiday that a bride and groom have straight after their wedding. Neelam and Vishal spent their honeymoon at the Barrier Reef.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb honeymoon We honeymooned in Tasmania.

form.definition: adjective If you have an honorary job or position, you do the work without being paid. Emil has been elected honorary treasurer of the sports club.

adjective If you have an honorary title or are an honorary member of an organisation, you are given the title or allowed to be a member as a mark of special recognition. The university awarded him an honorary degree for his contribution to Australian literature.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with honourable.

form.definition: noun Honour is being treated with great respect and admiration by people in general. His success did not bring him the honour he deserved.
noun If something that happens to you is an honour, you are very pleased and proud about it. It was an honour to be chosen team captain.
verb If you honour an arrangement or a promise, you do what you have agreed to do. The job wasn't finished on time as the builders didn't honour their contract.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is honor. ... WORD FAMILYverb honour The city honoured the explorer by erecting a statue of him.

form.definition: adjective If someone or something is honourable, they are decent and well-meaning. You can rely on them to do the right thing. It wouldn't be honourable to back out now.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is honorable.[qr

form.definition: noun A hood is a soft covering for your head and neck. It is usually attached to the top of a coat or cloak and hangs down the back when it isn't being worn.
noun A hood is also a folding roof over a car or baby's pram.
noun A hoodlum is someone who behaves in a destructive and violent way.
verb If someone hoodwinks you, they deceive or trick you because you don't really understand what is happening. Lee was too smart to be hoodwinked into paying more than his share.
noun A hoof is the hard part under the foot of animals such as horses, cows and deer.[qr

dictionary.entry:
hookhUk
noun A hook is a curved piece of metal or plastic that is used to hang things on or to hold things in place. Harold took off his hat and hung it on a hook in the wall.
by hook or by crook If you say you will achieve something by hook or by crook, you mean that you are determined to succeed somehow, even if it is very difficult and you have to try several different ways. Anjali was determined to get her promotion by hook or by crook.
hooked In informal language, if you say you are hooked on something, you mean that you really enjoy it and want to do it as much as possible. Neil is really hooked on golfhe's out playing every weekend.
... WORD FAMILYverb hook I hooked the door open.

form.definition: noun A hooligan is a noisy, disorderly person who causes trouble.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hooliganism

form.definition: noun In informal language, a hoon is a person who is loud and careless, especially someone who drives a car recklessly.
noun A hoop is a large circular band made from a rigid material such as metal or wood. The barrels are bound with metal hoops. He taught the dog to jump through a hoop.
verb When animals hop, they jump with all their feet together. The kangaroos hopped into the bushes as we got nearer.
If you hop somewhere, you move there fairly quickly and casually. Hop in and I'll give you a lift to work. Could you hop next door and ask when they'll be ready?
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hop The flight from Sydney to Melbourne is only a short hop.

form.definition: noun Hope is believing that something you want may happen. Hope is fading for the missing teenager. I'd almost given up hope when at last I found it. I travelled all this way in the hope of seeing him.
noun If you have a hope of doing something, there is a chance that you may be able to do it. We're so late now we've got no hope of catching the bus.

verb If you hope that something is the case, you want it to be so. You often use this word in polite enquiries. I hope Greg gets here soon, or we'll have to start without him. I hope you slept well. I do hope your mother will be better soon. You found your way here easily, I hope.
verb If you hope to do something, you intend to do it, in a rather vague way. I hope to visit Europe one day. What are you hoping to do with this qualification?

adjective If someone is hopeful, they are optimistic and think that things may turn out well. I felt much more hopeful in the morning. The doctors are hopeful that she'll recover fully. I'm not very hopeful about my chancesthe interview didn't go well.
adjective If something is hopeful, it is encouraging and makes you think that things may turn out well. He's already regained consciousnessthat's a hopeful sign.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb hopefully Clare looked up hopefully as I entered. Hopefully there'll be no more delays.

form.definition: adjective If a situation is hopeless, there is nothing that can be done to make it better. By the time she reached hospital she was a hopeless case.

adjective In informal language, if you say you are hopeless at something, you mean you have no skill or talent for it. I'm hopeless at gardeningI wouldn't know a plant from a weed. Sue was a hopeless navigatorwe got lost three times. No, do it like thishonestly, you're hopeless.
adjective In informal language, you use hopeless with some words to show how bad the thing is. The whole room was in a hopeless mess.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb hopelessly

form.definition: noun A horde is a large number of people or animals that you regard as unpleasant or threatening in some way. You can tell it's the school holidaysthe shopping centres are full of hordes of noisy children. The house is infested with a horde of rats.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with hoard.

form.definition: noun The horizon is the line in the distance where the sky seems to meet the land or the sea. A cloud of dust appeared on the horizon. The sun sank below the horizon.
adjective If something is horizontal, it is flat instead of being upright. She drew a horizontal line across the page. Use a spirit level to check the shelves are perfectly horizontal.
form.note: ... THE OPPOSITEof this is vertical. ... WORD FAMILYadverb horizontally

form.definition: noun A hormone is a chemical substance produced by a gland in the body. It affects the working of other parts of the body.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hormonal

form.definition: noun Horns are hard, pointed growths on the heads of animals such as cows and rams.
noun A horn is a musical wind instrument, usually made of brass.
noun A horn is a device on a vehicle that makes a loud noise to give a warning. Toot the hornthat car's about to back into us.

noun A horoscope is a diagram that shows the position of the planets in the sky at the time of your birth. This is used to forecast your future. Do you believe in horoscopes? My horoscope in the paper said that today was a good day for making changes.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is horrendous, you mean that it is very severe or unpleasant. There have been horrendous delays at the airport. My first job was a horrendous experience. ... WORD FAMILYadverb horrendously It all looks horrendously complicated. I'm horrendously late already.
adjective If something is horrible, it makes you very afraid or disgusted. I didn't sleep wellI had horrible nightmares. Suddenly she realised the horrible truth.

adjective In informal language, if you say something is horrible, you mean that it is unpleasant. This food tastes horrible! I had a horrible day at work todayeverything went wrong. The weather's been horrible all week.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb horribly The corpse was horribly mutilated.

form.definition: verb If something horrifies you or you are horrified by it, you are very shocked, surprised or distressed by it. You think it's very bad. It horrifies me the way they neglect their children. You'll be horrified when you see their new curtainsthey're purple with yellow stripes!
noun Horror is a very strong feeling of fear and disgust. Liam's always had a horror of snakes.

noun In informal language, if you say something or someone is a horror, you mean that it is difficult or unpleasant to deal with them. Apparently the auditors discovered some real horrors. Her children are a pair of horrorsshe just doesn't make them behave.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective horror I love those old horror movies.adjective horrific She suffered horrific injuries in the smash.

form.definition: noun An hors d'oeuvre is a small, savoury piece of food usually served with drinks before a main meal. These freshly prepared hors d'oeuvres are delicious.
noun A horse is a large animal with four legs, hoofs, and a flowing tail and mane. It can pull things along and you can ride it. A male horse is called a stallion and a female horse is called a mare.
eat like a horse If you eat like a horse, you eat a lot. You have a big appetite. The kids eat like horsesI couldn't believe how much food they put away.

from the horse's mouth If you hear something from the horse's mouth, you are told it by the person concerned, so you can be sure it is true. You can believe thisit came straight from the horse's mouth.

hold your horses If someone tells you to hold your horses, they mean that you should not rush into doing something. You've got a whole week to sort it out, so hold your horses and work out carefully how to do it. Hold your horses, I haven't said you can go yet.
noun A horseshoe is a U-shaped metal plate which is nailed to the bottom of a horse's hoof to protect it.
noun Horticulture is growing flowers, fruit and vegetables.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective horticultural

form.definition: noun A hose is a long, flexible tube made of rubber or plastic for carrying water. I need a new garden hose so I can water the plants. You should use a broom not a hose to clean the patio, and save water. The firefighters trained their hoses on the blaze.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hose The surfaces are hosed continuously to keep them wet.

form.definition: noun Hosiery is a formal word for socks, stockings and tights.
noun A hospice is a hospital where patients who are dying can receive special care.
noun A hospital is an institution where sick and injured people get medical treatment. I had to spend a week in hospital. The injured were taken to hospital.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hospitalise (<or> hospitalize) Kim was hospitalised for two weeks after his heart attack.

form.definition: noun Hospitality is the welcome you give to your guests and the food and accommodation you provide for them. We were grateful for our friends' hospitality while travelling overseas.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hospitable Sven was really hospitable and made us feel completely at home.

form.definition: noun A host is a person who entertains guests, for example by giving a party or having them to stay. We said goodbye and thanked our host for a wonderful party.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb host Sydney was chosen to host the Olympic Games in 2000.

form.definition: noun A hostage is a person who is kept as a prisoner by an individual or an organisation in an attempt to force the authorities or the hostage's family to meet their demands.
noun A hostel is an institution where people can get cheap accommodation, usually with shared facilities for cooking and washing. Mark lived in a hostel while studying at university.
adjective If someone is hostile, they are unfriendly and aggressive. His presentation met with a hostile reception. The unions were naturally hostile to the idea of retrenchments.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hostility

form.definition: adjective If something is hot, it has a high temperature. Be careful you don't burn yourself on the hot stove. The tea is still too hot to drink. It's been really hot all week. b adjective If you are hot, you have a sensation of being very warm. Phew, I'm hotI could really do with a cool drink.

adjective If food is hot, it has a lot of spices in it that produce a burning sensation on your tongue when you eat it. Evan's mouth was burning after eating hot chillies. I like mild curries, but not anything really hot.
adjective If news is hot, it is recent or fresh. I've just heard some hot news about Thomashe's leaving the company in disgrace.
adjective In informal language, if you say goods are hot, you mean they are stolen or illegally acquired. Someone was selling watches in the pubI suspect they're hot.
hot under the collar If someone is hot under the collar, they are angry and upset. There's no need to get hot under the collarit was only a joke.
hot up If something hots up, it becomes more active or exciting. The party only began to hot up after midnight. The police are hotting up their campaign against speeding.

in hot water If someone is in hot water, they are in trouble, usually because they have been discovered doing something wrong. Those kids are naughtythey're always getting into hot water. Mike's firm's lost a lot of money latelythey're really in hot water.

not so hot In informal language, if you say something is not so hot, you mean that it is disappointing or unsuccessful. 'How's your new business doing?' 'Not so hot, unfortunately.' The movie turned out to be not so hot.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See heat.

form.definition: noun Hot chips are long, thin pieces of potato that have been freshly fried.
noun A hot dog is a sausage or frankfurt served in a long bread roll with mustard or tomato sauce.

noun A hotel is a place where you can stay when you are on holiday or travelling on business. It has many rooms and usually restaurants, bars and services such as a laundry. We're going to the Barrier Reef for our holidays and staying at a new luxury hotel.
noun Hotel is also a more formal word for pub. A fight broke out at the hotel on Saturday night and the police were called.
noun A hothouse is a building for growing plants in. It is usually made of glass and is often heated.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is greenhouse.

form.definition: noun A hotline is a telephone line set up for a special purpose, such as for people to make enquiries in case of an emergency.
noun A hotplate is a metal plate on the top of an electric stove or barbecue. When it is heated you can cook food on it.
noun A hound is a dog, particularly a hunting dog.
verb If you hound someone, you constantly nag them or harass them. The couple were hounded by reporters and photographers wherever they went.
noun An hour is a measurement of time equal to sixty minutes. It'll take about four hours to drive there. I try to get eight hours sleep a night.

noun An hour is a particular period of time in the day. I'll ring you in my lunch hour. Let's wait till the peak hour is over before we drive into town. After business hours, you can contact me on this number. He keeps irregular hours.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hourly What's the hourly rate of pay?adverb hourly The temperature is measured hourly.

dictionary.entry:
househa:Us <for the noun>; <for the verb>, /\times,0\haz/ 1a noun A house is a building that people live in.
noun A house is also a building used for a particular purpose. Yanica lives in a boarding house near where she works. They built a summer house in the grounds of the main building. The monkey house was my favourite part of the zoo.
noun Each division of parliament is called a house. There is an upper house and a lower house.
noun The house is the seating for the audience in a theatre or cinema. There wasn't an empty seat in the house. HOUSE FULL They performed to a full house again.
verb If you house someone or something, you provide space for them to live or be stored. There was nowhere to house the large number of refugees. Thousands of books are housed in the public library.
on the house If something at a restaurant or hotel is on the house, you don't have to pay for it. The next round of drinks is on the house, with the compliments of the management.
... BE CAREFULwith the pronunciation of the plural . ... WORD FAMILYnoun housing There is a shortage of housing in the inner-city suburbs.
`ha:Uz@z

form.definition: noun A housebreaker is a thief who breaks into houses in order to steal valuables.
form.note: ... ANOTHER WORDfor this is burglar.

form.definition: noun A household is a group of people who live in the same accommodation. The crying baby kept the whole household awake. Most households in Australia have a TV.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective household We must cut down on household expenses. We share the household chores.

form.definition: noun Housekeeping is the work involved in running a home, such as shopping, cooking, cleaning and maintenance. Housekeeping for a large family can be a full-time job.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun housekeeper The rich family employed a housekeeper to run the house.

form.definition: noun A house-warming is a party you give when you move into a new home.
noun A housewife is a woman who does not have a paid job, but looks after her family at home.
noun Housework is work such as cleaning and washing that you do to keepyour home pleasant to live in. I make the children help with the housework.
form.note: ... DO NOT CONFUSEthis with homework.

form.definition: noun A hovel is a small, shabby house or hut.
verb When birds or insects hover, they stay in one spot in the air. Look at the insects hovering over the pond.
verb If you hover, you stay around somewhere because you aren't sure what to do. James hovered in the background in case he was needed to help.

dictionary.entry: hovercraft`hOv@kra:fthovercraft noun A hovercraft is a vehicle that travels across water or land supported on a cushion of air.

form.definition: adverb You use how when you want to know in what way or by what means something happens or is done. How did you get hurt? How do you work this video?
adverb You use how when you refer to the extent or degree of something. I'm surprised how peaceful this place is. How much is it? How hungry are you?
adverb You use how when you want to know in what condition of health someone is. How are you? How's your sore back? How are you doing? How are you going?

adverb If you ask someone in a surprised way how they could have done something, you are amazed at what they have done. There were at least ten chocolates in the boxhow could you eat them all! How can he say he doesn't care when he knows it is important.
conjunction How can also be used to introduce an indirect statement. Nino told me how to get to the station. John didn't mind how much he spent. I wonder how Julie feels these days.
how do you do You say how do you do to a person as a greeting when you are formally introduced.
form.note: ... NOTEYou only use this with the pronoun you.

form.definition: how would you like You can use the phrase how would you like when you are making a suggestion or an offer. How would you like to go out to dinner tonight? You'll never finish this work in timehow would you like me to give you a hand.
adverb However is a formal word used to emphasise a contrast with something else you say or with what might be expected. I'd love to go to the movies; however, I haven't got the time.
adverb However also means 'in whatever way'. You can have the steak cooked however you like it.
adverb However also means 'no matter to what extent'. I'm not going to accept the offer however attractive it looks.
verb If a dog or wolf howls, it makes a long, loud, crying sound.
verb When the wind howls, it blows strongly and makes a lot of noise.

howl down If you howl a speaker down, you jeer at them so loudly that what they are saying can't be heard. It was a poor performance and towards the end the actors were howled down by the audience. Peter's suggestion that we should all stay late was immediately howled down.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun howl This comment was greeted with a howl of derision.

form.definition: abbreviation for headquarters. The command came from army HQ. Roger's been transferred to regional HQ.
abbreviation for hour. WALKING TRACK TO LOOKOUT: 1 HR RETURN
abbreviation for Higher School Certificate.
abbreviation for height. LOW BRIDGEMAXIMUM HT 6 METRES
noun The hub of a wheel is its central part.
noun A hub is also the central and most important part of a busy place. Jaron's office is in the hub of the business district.
verb If you huddle somewhere, you keep the parts of your body tightly together so that you don't take up much space. The children huddled under the blankets to keep warm.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun huddle They went into a huddle and then told me that I'd got the job.

form.definition: noun Hue is a formal word for a colour or a particular shade of a colour. The blue hues of the ocean around the coral reefs are truly spectacular on a sunny day.

dictionary.entry: hughV ghugshuggedhugging verb If you hug someone, you squeeze them tightly with your arms to show your affection for them. We all hugged Anne before she got on her plane. ... WORD FAMILYnoun hug You deserve a great big hug!

form.definition: adjective If something is huge, it is very large. The elephant is a huge animal. Within three months he'd run up a huge debt.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hugeness

form.definition: noun In informal language, if someone or something is large, heavy or clumsy, you can describe them as a hulk. Her eldest son is a real hulkplenty of muscle but no brains. I want an elegant desk, not a great hulk like that.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hulking We were confronted by a hulking security guard.

form.definition: noun The hull of a ship is the main part of it that floats in the water.
interjection Hullo is another spelling of hello.
verb When something hums, it makes a continuous low sound. On a warm spring day you can hear the bees humming in the flowering gums.
verb When you hum, you sing a tune with your lips closed. Lucy hummed a tune as she walked along. Do stop hummingit's really irritating!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hum I soon grew used to the hum of the fan.

form.definition: adjective Human means relating to people. They discovered human remains in the ditch. It's only human to want to relate to others. Rex is such a clever dog, he seems almost human.
noun A human or human being is a persona man, woman or child. The ceremony marks contact between humans and the gods. Human beings are believed to have ape-like ancestors.

adjective If you are humane, you treat people and animals with kindness. You are not cruel. I thought it was more humane not to let him know how sick he was. There must be more humane ways of destroying the feral animals.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See humanity.adverb humanely

form.definition: adjective If something is described as humanitarian, it is concerned with relieving suffering. The company donates considerable sums to humanitarian causes.
noun Humanity is people as a whole. These moral issues have been of importance throughout the history of humanity.
noun Humanity is not being cruel to people or animals. The prisoners were treated with humanity.
adjective If you are humble, you do not boast or feel proud about what you have achieved. Many religions teach that it is virtuous to be humble.
adjective If someone or something is humble, they are low in status. Seth had worked as a humble servant all his life. Edith came from a humble home.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun See humility.adverb humbly

form.definition: adjective If something is humdrum, it is boring and lacks variety. I was fed up with my humdrum way of life. Working in an office can be pretty humdrum.
adjective When the weather is humid, the air feels damp and sticky. The plants in the hothouse thrive on the humid atmosphere.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun humidity

form.definition: verb If someone humiliates you, they make you feel embarrassed. Ned deserves to be humiliated for playing dirty tricks on people. How dare you humiliate me in front of my friends!
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun humiliation

form.definition: noun Humility is being humble. Despite his fame he was a man of great humility and charm.
noun Humour is being funny. The novel was light-hearted and full of humour.
sense of humour Your sense of humour is what you find funny. We get on well because we've got the same sense of humour. Adam seems to have absolutely no sense of humour.
form.note: ... ANOTHER SPELLINGfor this is humor. ... WORD FAMILYadjective humorous ...a humorous novel.[qr

dictionary.entry:
humphV mp
noun A hump is a large lump rising out of the surface of something. The Arabian camel has one hump and the Bactrian camel has two humps. I can't get the carpet to lie flat without humps.

form.definition: noun A humpy is a hut or simple shelter used by Aborigines in the bush.
noun In informal language, a hunch is an intuition you have about something. I had a hunch that he was going to announce his resignation. Her hunch was correctDavid was in the library.
noun Hundred is the number 100, ten lots of ten. If you score over a hundred you're doing very well.
adjective If you have a hundred things, the number of things you have adds up to one hundred. More than a hundred people turned up for the meeting.
hundreds In informal language, you can use hundreds to mean a large number. I'm going to be busy todayI've got hundreds of letters to write.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hundredth

form.definition: verb Hung is the past tense and past participle of hang.
adjective If someone or something comes from Hungary, you describe them as Hungarian.
noun Hungarian is the language of Hungary.
noun Hunger is the feeling you get when you need to eat. Maureen didn't stay on the diet for longshe couldn't put up with the hunger between meals.
noun Hunger is also a lack of food to eat. Millions of people in the world live in poverty and hunger.

noun Hunger is also a strong desire for something. Bradley couldn't settle down for longhe had a hunger for travel. ... WORD FAMILYverb hunger These children hunger for affection.adjective hungry (hungrier, hungriest) It's an hour till lunchtime but I'm hungry already.adverb hungrily
verb If someone hunts wild animals, they try to find and kill them. Some farmers hunt the kangaroos because they can be a pest.
verb If you hunt for something, you search for it. You try to find it. I've hunted everywhere but I can't find the other sock.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hunt I'm on the hunt for a new wardrobe.noun hunter The joey's mother had been killed by hunters.

form.definition: noun A hurdle is a fence that runners or horses have to jump over in certain races.
noun A hurdle is a problem or difficulty that you have to overcome in order to achieve what you want. The venture is unlikely to succeedthere are too many hurdles in the way.
verb If you hurl something, you throw it violently. Demonstrators hurled missiles at the police.
interjection Hurray is an exclamation of joy and approval. Hurray, that's got it working at last. Let's give the winner a big cheer: hip, hip, hurray!
form.note: ... OTHER SPELLINGSfor this are hurrah and hooray.

form.definition: noun A hurricane is a violent storm with very strong winds. Several boats were wrecked in the hurricane.

verb If you hurry, you move or act quickly. Elsa hurried to the station to catch the train. The waiter hurried after me with my umbrella. We'll have to hurry to finish in time. You can't hurry the healing process.
hurry up If you tell someone to hurry up, you want them to act more quickly or sooner. Hurry up with your homeworkit's getting late. I wish he'd hurry up and call.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hurry There's no hurryslow down. Where can I get printing done in a hurry?adjective hurried I gave the report a hurried glance.adverb hurriedly She hurriedly assured me that it wasn't my fault.

form.definition: verb If a part of your body hurts, it is painful or sore. My feet hurt after the long walk. My wrist hurts when I bend it. It hurts to turn my head. Does that hurt? Show me where it hurts.
verb If someone or something hurts you, they cause you pain or injure you. I'm sorry I trod on your footdid I hurt you? Fifteen people were hurt in the bus smash.
verb If something hurts you, it upsets you. Her hostility really hurt me. It hurts me to think of their suffering.
verb If something hurts something else, it damages or spoils it. The unexpected repair bill really hurt my budget. It won't hurt them to wait a bit longer.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective See hurtful.noun hurt She found it hard to forgive the hurt he had caused her.

form.definition: adjective If someone's words or actions are hurtful, they are unkind and make you unhappy.
verb If something hurtles, it moves quickly and often in an uncontrolled way. The truck hurtled down the hill and screeched to a halt. He went hurtling off without waiting to get directions.
noun A woman's husband is the man she is married to.
verb If you hush someone, you tell or signal them to be quiet. The teacher hushed the class before the principal came in.
interjection You say hush to someone if you want them to be quiet. Hush! Mario will hear us if you don't stop that noise.
hush up If you hush something up, you prevent it from becoming known by the public. The scandal was hushed up by the government.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hush Suddenly the noise stopped and a hush fell over the room.

form.definition: noun A husk is the dry outside covering of grains and some seeds.
adjective If your voice is husky, it sounds slightly hoarse. My voice is going huskyI hope I'm not getting a cold. She spoke in a husky whisper that she imagined to be sexy.
adjective If someone is husky, they are big and strong. We need someone husky on the door to keep out troublemakers.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadverb huskily noun huskiness

form.definition: verb If you hustle someone somewhere, you force or push them to make them move quickly. Police hustled the prisoners through the crowd into the courtroom.
verb If you hustle someone, you try to get them to do what you want by putting pressure on them. I want to think it overI won't be hustled into a decision.
noun A hut is a small building with a simple structure, often made of wood. The workers are accommodated in huts on the site.
noun A hutch is a small cage for keeping animals in.
abbreviation for highway.
noun A hybrid is something that has the characteristics of two or more different things. This pen is a hybrid between a ballpoint and a fountain pen.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hybrid I bought a hybrid mixer and blender.

form.definition: noun A hydrant is a pipe where you can attach a hose to get water from a main supply. Contractors pay for licences to draw water from the hydrants. This map shows the position of all the fire hydrants in the area.
adjective Hydraulic equipment is operated or controlled by the pressure of a liquid such as water or oil. Modern cars all have hydraulic brakes.
adjective Hydro-electric power is electricity generated by the energy of falling water.
noun A hydrofoil is a boat equipped with floats that raise its hull above the water when it travels at high speed.
noun Hydroponics is growing plants in water containing certain chemicals instead of in soil.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hydroponic

form.definition: noun Hygiene is keeping things clean in order to prevent the spread of infection and disease. Improved hygiene caused a dramatic reduction in the number of deaths. His personal hygiene leaves a lot to be desired.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hygienic The kitchens didn't look very hygienic.

form.definition: noun A hymn is a religious song expressing praise.
noun In informal language, hype is great excitement and enthusiasm that has been deliberately created. There's been so much hype about the movieI'm sick of hearing about it!
adjective In informal language, if you say someone is hyped-up, you mean they are very excited. The boys were hyped-up because they were about to leave for their camp in the valley.

noun A hyphen is a short line used to join words to show that they form a compound, e.g. hold-up. It is also used to show that two vowels are pronounced separately, e.g. co-operate, and when a word is split between two lines.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYverb hyphenate

form.definition: noun Hypnosis is a sleep-like state in which you may be able to remember things that you had forgotten while awake. Under hypnosis she relived the whole experience.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hypnotise (<or> hypnotize) Andrea agreed to be hypnotised as an experiment.noun hypnotism Matthew is studying hypnotism.noun hypnotist

form.definition: noun A hypochondriac is someone who worries a great deal about their health and often imagines that they are sick.
noun A hypocrite is someone who expects other people to be moral but doesn't behave that way themselves. The senator was exposed as a hypocrite when his correspondence was made public.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYnoun hypocrisy adjective hypocritical

form.definition: adjective A hypodermic syringe is used to inject drugs under the skin.

noun A hypothesis is an idea put forward to explain something. It fits the facts, but has not been definitely proved. My hypothesis is that Joan did it to discredit Tamsin. Scientists are seeking evidence to confirm this interesting hypothesis.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hypothetical The students were given a hypothetical case to study.

form.definition: noun If a woman has a hysterectomy, she has her uterus surgically removed.
noun Hysteria is a state of extreme excitement or panic. Mass hysteria broke out as bullets were fired at the crowd.
noun Hysteria is also a psychological condition in which the patient has uncontrollable outbursts of emotion.
form.note: ... WORD FAMILYadjective hysterical The symptoms are apparently hysterical in origin.adverb hysterically He wept hysterically at the sight. The movie is hysterically funny.[fa[xp
